explanations: The original metaphorical and polite request ('start again a little, if you please, to speak Chaldean to me') is simplified into a more direct, concrete demand for instruction, losing the polite phrasing and nuance of continuing a style of discourse.
The formal, slightly abstract French question ('what was it a matter of?') is simplified by rendering it as a more direct and colloquial English question.

The somewhat literary French phrase 'leur réjoüir la veüe' (to rejoice their sight/view) is simplified to the more common English 'please our sight,' also clarifying the possessive pronoun from the potentially ambiguous 'leur' (their) to 'our'.

The idiomatic French double negative 'on ne manqua pas de s'imaginer' (one did not fail to imagine) is simplified to a direct affirmative 'they imagin'd.' The adverb 'd'abord' (at first) is also omitted, reducing textual density.

The original's self-aware comment 'Je puis me vanter' (I can boast) is omitted, and the nuanced description of the act 'adoucis bien tout ce Sistême' (I am greatly softening this whole system for you) is simplified to the more direct and common 'I will make it plainer.'

The strong, vivid French expression 'il vous jetteroit dans une épouvante horrible' (it would throw you into a horrible fright/terror) is simplified to 'I should fright you,' using less intense vocabulary and reducing the dramatic imagery.

This specific descriptive phrase from the French original, 'tantost en un sens, tantost en un autre,' (sometimes in one direction, sometimes in another) detailing the irregularity of planetary motion, is omitted from the English translation, simplifying the list of irregularities by reducing detail.

This entire parenthetical comment by Fontenelle, which offers a humorous reflection on the Ptolemaic system being an 'occasion of sin' due to its confusion, is omitted in the translation. This simplifies the text by removing a digression, thereby reducing its density and stylistic complexity.

The word 'Apparemment' (apparently/seemingly) from the French original, which introduced a slight nuance of speculation regarding the King's advice, is omitted in the English translation. This makes the statement more direct and less hedged.

The impersonal statement of necessity 'Il le faloit absolument' (It was absolutely necessary) is simplified to a personal dictate 'Aristotle would have it so,' making the concept less abstract and attributing the necessity directly to Aristotle's authority.

The formal French phrase '& il a falu se resoudre à faire les Cieux d'une matiere fluide' (and it was necessary to resolve to make the Heavens of a fluid matter) is replaced by the much more colloquial idiom 'But to make the best of a bad Market' and vivid, less formal imagery ('they presently melt down their broken Glass'), simplifying the tone and register.

The formal French 'l'ancien Sistême est absolument insoûtenable par cet endroit' (the ancient system is absolutely untenable on this point) is rendered by the more common 'exploded' (discredited). The translator then adds the very colloquial and dismissive English idiom 'and all the Ipse Dixits not worth a rush,' simplifying the academic critique into a more populist and emphatic dismissal.

This clause from the French original, 'car il est d'une simplicité charmante, & qui seule le feroit préferer' (for it is of a charming simplicity, and which alone would make it preferable), which explains the reason for preferring the new system, is omitted from the corresponding English sentence. This omission simplifies the argument by reducing explanatory detail.

The complex French sentence, 'tout ce qu'elle pourra faire d'une maniere qui luy coûtera un peu moins, quand ce moins ne seroit presque rien, soyez seure qu'elle ne le fera que de cette maniere-là,' with its elaborate conditional and emphatic structure detailing Nature's extreme economy, is simplified into a much more concise and direct English statement.

The first sentence of Fontenelle's two-part philosophical point, 'Nous mettons l'épargne dans le dessein qu'a eu la Nature, & la magnificence dans l'execution' (We attribute thrift to Nature's design and magnificence to its execution), is omitted. The English translation renders only the second part of the argument. This omission simplifies the overall philosophical point by removing one of its premises, thereby reducing complexity and density.

The Marquise's expression of desire 'Je serai bien-aise... que le Sistême... imite...' (I will be very glad... that the System... imitates...) and her complex subordinate clause explaining the benefit to her imagination ('car ce grand ménage-là tournera au profit de mon imagination, qui n'aura pas tant de peine à comprendre...') are simplified into a direct command ('Imitate Nature then...') and a straightforward request ('and give me as little trouble as you can to comprehend you'). This simplifies sentence structure, mood, and drastically reduces explanatory content.

The concise French idiom 'fait main basse sur' (makes a clean sweep of / seizes / plunders) is expanded into a series of more common verbs ('confounding everything, earing [tearing] in pieces... shattering...'). The addition of the simile 'like so many Glass Windows' simplifies the destructive action by making it more concrete and visually accessible, even though it increases length.

The relatively formal French phrase 'l'envoye bien loin du centre de l'Univers' (sends it very far from the center of the Universe) is simplified by the use of the colloquial English idiom 'sends her packing.' The subordinate clause 'où elle s'estoit placée' (where it had placed itself) is also omitted, reducing detail and simplifying the sentence.

The Marquise's elaborated complaint 'il vient de vous prendre un enthousiasme qui vous a fait expliquer les choses si pompeusement, que je ne croy pas les avoir entenduës' (an enthusiasm has just taken you which made you explain things so pompously, that I don't think I understood them) is simplified into the more concise 'a little less Rapture, and I shall understand you the better.' This reduces the complexity of the cause-and-effect structure and shortens the phrasing.

The introductory French phrase 'vous voyez bien que...' (you see well/clearly that...) is omitted. Furthermore, the somewhat formal consequential structure 'aussi employe-t-il plus de temps...' (also/therefore it uses more time...) is replaced by the simpler and more common English causal connector 'which is the reason he is a longer time...'.
The somewhat formal French idiom 'Je luy sçay bon gré' (I am grateful to him / I give him credit for) is simplified to the more colloquial and direct English phrase ''Twas well done of him.'

The general observation about 'on' (people in general) being less jealous of their universal rank than their rank 'dans une chambre' (in a room, implying social settings) is simplified by making it a more concrete and specific scenario involving 'a Fair Lady' and her concern for her place 'at a Ball.' This narrows the scope and uses more common social imagery for easier comprehension.

The French idiom 'se tira habilement d'affaire' (cleverly got himself out of the affair/trouble) is simplified by the use of the very common and more direct English idiom '(very) wisely slipt out of the way.'

The periphrastic French construction 'Je voy, ce me semble, à vostre air, que vous m'allez dire...' (I see, it seems to me, by your air/expression, that you are going to tell me...) is drastically simplified by being reduced to the concise 'Perhaps you will tell me...'. This removes the observational details and uses a common modal adverb, shortening the sentence and making it more direct.

The rhetorical question 'N'ai-je pas oüy dire que...' (Haven't I heard it said that...), which introduces the anecdote, is simplified into a direct affirmative statement 'For I have heard of...'. This makes the sentence structure more straightforward and less nuanced.

The Marquise's indirect and formal statement 'Vous jugez bien qu'il ne m'appartient point de faire ces pas-là' (You can well imagine that it is not for me to make those steps) is simplified into a direct command to the philosopher: 'But you may spare your Figures.' Additionally, the impersonal 'qu'il ne faut pas qu'on en voie icy' (and that one must not see any here / they shouldn't be seen here) becomes the more direct and judgmental 'such Footsteps are not decent here.'

chunks.sourceHtml:
P009: Il vaut mieux en effet, répondis-je, qu'on n'y voy que des pas d'Amans, c'est-à- dire, votre nom & vos chiffres, gravez sur l'écorce des arbres par la main de vos Adorateurs. Laissons-là, je vous prie, les Adorateurs, reprit-elle, & parlons du Soleil. J'entends bien comment nous nous imaginons qu'il décrit le cercle que nous décrivons nous- mêmes, mais ce tour ne s'acheve qu'en un an, & celuy que le Soleil fait tous les jours sur notre tête, comment se fait-il? Avez-vous remarqué, lui répondis-je, qu'une boule qui roule sur la Terre, a deux mouvemens? Elle va vers le but où elle est envoyée, & en même temps elle tourne un grand nombre de fois sur elle-même, en sorte que les parties d'en haut viennent en bas, & que celles d'en bas montent en haut. La Terre fait la même chose. Dans le temps qu'elle avance sur le Cercle qu'elle décrit en un an autour du Soleil, elle tourne sur elle-même en vingt-quatre heures. Ainsi en vingt-quatre heures chaque partie de la Terre perd le Soleil, & le recouvre, & à mesure qu'en tourne vers le côté où est le Soleil, il semble qu'il s'élève, & quand on commence à s'en éloigner, il semble qu'il s'abaisse. Cela est assez plaisant, dit-elle, la Terre prend tout sur soy, & ce Soleil ne fait rien. Et quand la Lune & les autres Planètes, les Etoiles Fixes paroissent faire un tour sur notre tête en vingt-quatre heures, c'est donc aussi une imagination? Imagination pure, repris-je, qui vient de la même cause. Les Planètes font seulement leurs Cercles autour du Soleil en des temps inégaux selon leurs distances inégales, & celle que nous voyons aujourd'huy répondre à un certain point du Zodiaque, ou de ce Cercle d'Etoiles Fixes, nous la voyons demain répondre à un autre point, tant parce qu'elle a avancé sur son Cercle, que parce que nous avons avancé sur le nôtre. Nous marchons, & les autres Planètes marchent aussi; cela nous met dans diférens points de veüe à leur égard, & nous fait paroître dans leur cours des bizarreries dont il n'est pas nécessaire que je vous parle. Il suffit que vous sachiez que ce qu'il y a d'irrégulier dans les Planètes ne vient que de la diverse maniere dont notre mouvement nous les fait rencontrer, & qu'au fond elles sont toutes très-reglées. Je consens qu'elles le soient, dit la Marquise, mais je voudrois bien que leur regularité coûtât moins à la Terre, on ne l'a guere ménagée, & pour une grosse masse aussi pesante qu'elle est, on luy demande bien de l'agilité.. Mais, lui répondis-je, aimeriez-vous mieux que le Soleil, & tous les autres Astres qui sont de très grands Corps, fissent en vingt-quatre heures autour de la Terre un tour immense, & un nombre infini de lieües? Car il faudroit qu'il le fissent si la Terra ne tournoit pas sut elle même en 24 heures.

P010: Oh! répliqua-t-elle, le Soleil & les Astres sont tout de feu, le mouvement ne leur coúte rien; mais la Terre ne paroît guere portative. Et croiriez-vous, repris-je, si vous n'en aviez point l'expérience, que ce fût quelque chose de bien portatif, qu'un gros Navire monté de cent cinquante pièces de Canon, chargé de plus de trois mille hommes, & d'une très grande nombre de Marchandises? Cependant il ne faut qu'un petit soufle de vent pour le faire aller sur l'eau, parce que l'eau est liquide, & que se laissant diviser avec facilité, elle résiste peu au mouvement du Navire. Ainsi la Terre, toute massive qu'elle est, est aisément portée dans la matiere celeste, qui est mille fois plus fluide que l'eau, & qui remplit tout ce grand espace où nagent les Planètes. Et où faudroit-il que la Terre fût cramponnée pour résister au mouvement de cette matière céleste, & ne pas s'y laisser emporter? C'est comme si une petite boule de bois pouvoit ne pas suivre le courant d'une Riviere.

P011: Mais, répliqua-t-elle encore, comment la Terre avec tout son poids se soûtient- elle sur votre matiere celeste qui doit être bien legere, puisqu'elle est si fluide? Ce n'est pas à dire, répondis-je, que ce qui est fluide, soit plus leger. Que dites-vous de notre gros Vaisseau, qui avec tout son poids est plus léger que l'eau, puisqu'il y surnage? Je ne veux plus vous dire rien, dit-elle comme en colere, tant que vous aurez le gros Vaisseau. Mais m'assurez-vous bien qu'il n'y ait rien à craindre sur une pirouette aussi legere que vous me faites la Terre? Eh bien, luy répondis-je, faisons porter la Terre par quatre Elephans, comme font les Indiens. Voicy bien un autre Système, s'écria-t-elle. Du moins j'aime ces Gens-là d'avoir pourveu à leur seureté, & fait de bons fondemens, au lieu que nous autres Coperniciens, nous sommes assez inconsideres pour vouloir bien nager à l'aventure dans cette matiere celeste. Je gage que si les Indiens savoient que la Terre fût le moins du monde en peril de se mouvoir, ils doubleroient les Elephans.

P012: Cela le meriteroit bien, repris-je, en riant de sa pensée, il ne faut point s'épargner les Elephans pour dormir en assurance, & si vous en avez besoin pour cette nuit, nous en mettrons dans notre systême autant qu'il vous plaira; ensuite nous les retrancherons peu à peu, à mesure que vous vous rassurerez. Serieusement, reprit-elle, je ne crois pas dés à present qu'ils me soient fort necessaires, & je me sens assez de courage pour oser tourner. Vous irez bien-tost encore plus loin, répliquai-je, vous tournerez avec plaisir, & vous vous ferez sur ce Systême des idées réjouissantes. Quelquefois, par exemple, je me figure que je suis suspendu en l'air, & que j'y demeure sans mouvement pendant que la Terre tourne sous moy en vingt-quatre heures, & que je vois passer sous mes yeux tous ces visages differens, les uns blancs, les autres noirs, les autres bazannez, les autres olivâtres, que je voy d'abord des Chapeaux, & puis des Turbans, & puis des têtes cheveluës, & puis des Têtes rases; tantôt des Villes à clochers, tantôt des Villes à longues aiguilles qui ont des Croissants, tantôt des Villes à Tours de Porcelaine, tantôt de grands Païs qui n'ont que des Cabanes; icy, des vastes Mers; là des Deserts épouvantables; enfin toute cette variété infinie qui est sur la surface de la Terre.

P013: En verité, dit-elle, tout cela mériteroit bien que l'on donnât vingt-quatre heures de son temps à le voir. Ainsi donc dans le même lieu où nous sommes à present, je ne dis pas dans ce Parc, mais dans ce même lieu, à le prendre dans l'air, il y passe continuellement d'autres Peuples qui prennent notre place, & au bout de vingt-quatre heures nous y revenons.
chunks.manualHtml: P007: I confess, said I, Madam, the footsteps of Lovers would better become this Place; that is, your Name and Cypher grav'd on the Trees by your Adorers. Tell not me, said she, of Lovers and Adorers, I am for my beloved Sun and Planets. But how comes it to pass that the Sun as to the fixed Stars compleats his course but in a year, and yet goes over our Heads every day? Did you never, I reply'd, observe a Bowl on a Bowling-green? It runs towards the Block, and at the same time turns very often round it self, so that the Parts which were above are below, and those which were below are above; just so it is with the Earth, at the same time that she advanceth on the Circle which in a years space she makes round the Sun, in twenty four hours she turns round her self; so that in twenty four hours every part of the Earth loseth the Sun, and recovers him again, and as it turns towards the Sun, it seems to rise, and as it turns from him, it seems to fall. It is very pleasant, said she, that the Earth must take all upon her self, and the Sun do nothing. And when the Moon, the other Planets, and the fix'd Stars seem to go over our Heads every twenty four hours, you'll say that too is only Fancy? Pure Fancy, said I, which proceeds from the same cause, for the Planets compleat their courses round the Sun at unequal times, according to their unequal distances, and that which we see to day answer to a certain Point in the Zodiack or Circle of the fix'd Stars, to morrow we see answer to another Point, because it is advanced on its own Circle as well as we are advanced upon ours. We move, and the Planets move too, which must make a great alteration; so that what seems irregular in the Planets, proceeds only from our motion, when in truth they are all very regular: I will suppose 'em so, said the Countess, but I would not have their Regularity put the Earth to so great trouble; methinks you exact too much Activity from so ponderous a Mass. But, said I, had you rather that the Sun and all the Stars, which are vast great Bodies, should in twenty four hours travel such an infinity of Miles, and make so prodigious a Tour as they needs must, if the Earth did not turn round it self every twenty four hours? Oh, said she, the Sun and the Stars are all Fire, their Motion is not very difficult; but the Earth, I fancy, is a little unweildy: That signifies nothing, I reply'd, for what do you think of a first rate Ship, which carries near an hundred Guns, and a thousand Men, beside her Provisions and other Furniture? you see one puff of Wind makes it sail on the Water, because the Water is liquid, and being easily separated doth very little resist the motion of the Ship: So the Earth tho' never so Massive is as easily born up by the Celestial Matter, which is a thousand times more fluid than the Water, and fills all that great Space where the Planets float; for where would you the Earth should be fastned to resist the motion of the Celestial Matter, and not be driven by it? You may as well fancy a little block of Wood can withstand the current of a River. But pray, said she, how can the Earth with all its weight be born up by your Celestial Matter, which must be very light, because it is so fluid? It doth not argue, said I, that what is most fluid is most light: for what think you of the great Vessel I mention'd but now, which with all its Burthen is yet lighter than the Water it floats on? I will have nothing to do with that great Vessel, said she, and I begin to apprehend my self in some danger on such a whirlegigg as you have made of the Earth: There is no danger, I reply'd; but Madam, if you are afraid, we will have the Earth supported by four Elephants, as the Indians believe it. Hey day, cry'd she, here's another Systeme; however I love those People for taking care of themselves, they have a good Foundation to trust to, while you Copernicans are a little too venturous with the Celestial Matter; and yet I fancy if the Indians thought the Earth in the least danger of sinking, they would double their number of Elephants. They do well, said I, laughing at her fancy, who would sleep in Fear? and if you have occasion for 'em to night, we will put as many as you please in our Systeme, we can take 'em away again by degrees as you grow better confirm'd. I do not think 'em very necessary, said she, I have courage enough to turn. You shall turn with pleasure, Madam, said I, and shall find delightful Ideas in this Systeme. For Example, sometimes I fancy my self suspended in the Air, without any motion, while the Earth turns round me in twenty four hours; I see I know not how many different Faces pass under me, some white, some black, and some tauny; sometimes I see Hats, and sometimes Turbants, now Heads with Hair, and then shav'd Heads; here I see Cities with Steeples, others with Spires and Crescents, others with Towers of Purcelain, and anon great Countreys with nothing but Cottages; here. I see vast Oceans, and there most horrible Desarts; in short, I discover the infinite variety which is upon the surface of the Earth. I confess, said she, twenty four hours would thus be very well bestow'd, so that in the same Place where we are now, I do not mean in the Park, but we will suppose our selves in the Air, other People continually pass by who take up our Place, and at the end of twenty four hours we return to it again.

explanations: The impersonal French construction 'qu'on n'y voy que' (that one only sees there) is rephrased into a more active and direct statement 'the footsteps of Lovers would better become this Place,' simplifying the original's slightly more abstract or observational tone. The substitution of 'I confess' for 'Il vaut mieux en effet' also personalizes the tone, which can be seen as a form of simplification by making it more conversational.

The polite French request 'Laissons-là, je vous prie... & parlons du Soleil' (Let's leave aside... I pray you, and let's talk about the Sun) is transformed into the more emphatic and colloquial 'Tell not me...' and the simpler, more direct expression of preference 'I am for my beloved Sun...'. This simplifies the expression of intent.

The initial clause 'J'entends bien comment nous nous imaginons qu'il décrit le cercle que nous décrivons nous- mêmes' (I understand well how we imagine that it describes the circle that we ourselves describe) is omitted. This significantly shortens the sentence and removes a layer of acknowledgement, simplifying the discourse by moving directly to the question.

The more descriptive French phrases 'vers le côté où est le Soleil' (towards the side where the Sun is) and 'quand on commence à s'en éloigner' (when one begins to move away from it) are simplified to the more direct 'towards the Sun' and 'from him [the Sun]'. This reduces descriptive detail for conciseness and easier comprehension.

The direct French question 'c'est donc aussi une imagination?' (is it then also an imagination?) is changed to 'you'll say that too is only Fancy?', a confirmation-seeking question directed at the philosopher. This simplifies the interrogative form by making it more personal and conversational.

The French 'tant... que...' construction, indicating two equally contributing reasons, is simplified to 'because... as well as...', which is a more linear and less complex way of presenting dual causality, making the sentence structure simpler.

The complex French passage is simplified by: 1. Replacing the descriptive 'cela nous met dans diférens points de veüe à leur égard' with the more conclusory 'which must make a great alteration'. 2. Omitting the meta-comment 'dont il n'est pas nécessaire que je vous parle'. 3. Omitting the framing 'Il suffit que vous sachiez que'. 4. Simplifying the nuanced 'la diverse maniere dont notre mouvement nous les fait rencontrer' to the more direct 'proceeds only from our motion'. This overall restructuring and omission significantly simplifies the argument and reduces its density.

The two French clauses using the impersonal 'on' ('on ne l'a guere ménagée'; 'on luy demande bien de l'agilité') are condensed and personalized into a single, more direct address: 'methinks you exact too much Activity...'. This simplifies the sentence structure by removing impersonal constructions and making the agent explicit.

The French subjunctive construction 'Car il faudroit qu'il le fissent' (For it would be necessary that they do so) is simplified to the more concise and idiomatic English 'as they needs must.' This avoids a more complex verb form and sentence structure.

The initial conditional hypothetical 'Et croiriez-vous... si vous n'en aviez point l'expérience, que ce fût...' (And would you believe... if you had no experience of it, that it was...) is omitted and replaced by the assertive 'That signifies nothing'. This simplifies the argument by removing a layer of complex hypothetical reasoning. Additionally, the specific numbers in the example are reduced (150 to 'near an hundred'; 'plus de trois mille' to 'a thousand'), simplifying the scale for the reader.

The slightly more formal French 'il ne faut qu'un petit soufle de vent pour le faire aller' (only a small puff of wind is needed to make it go) is simplified to the more direct, active, and conversational 'you see one puff of Wind makes it sail'.

The phrase 'comme en colere' (as if angry) is omitted, simplifying the description by removing emotional nuance. The expression 'Je ne veux plus vous dire rien' is rendered more concisely and idiomatically as 'I will have nothing to do with'.

The Marquise's direct question asking for assurance, 'Mais m'assurez-vous bien qu'il n'y ait rien à craindre...?' (But assure me well that there is nothing to fear...?), is transformed into a statement of her own feeling, 'and I begin to apprehend my self in some danger...'. This simplifies the directness of the request into a self-contained expression, altering the illocutionary force for simpler discourse.

The phrase 'assez inconsideres pour vouloir bien nager à l'aventure' (foolish/thoughtless enough to be willing to swim haphazardly/at random) is simplified to 'a little too venturous.' This uses less vivid and less critical vocabulary, softening the original's stronger implication and reducing stylistic richness.

The didactic statement 'il ne faut point s'épargner les Elephans pour dormir en assurance' (one must not spare the Elephants to sleep in safety) is replaced by the simpler, more conversational rhetorical question 'who would sleep in Fear?'. This conveys a similar sentiment using a simpler and more direct structure.

The adverb 'Serieusement' (Seriously), which marks a shift in tone, and the temporal phrase 'dés à present' (at present / from now on) are omitted. This makes the Marquise's statement more direct but removes nuance, simplifying the utterance.

The initial encouraging phrase 'Vous irez bien-tost encore plus loin' (You will soon go even further) is omitted. Furthermore, 'vous vous ferez sur ce Systême des idées réjouissantes' (you will form for yourself joyful ideas about this System), implying active mental construction, is simplified to the more passive 'shall find delightful Ideas'.

The list of four specific skin tones in French ('blancs,' 'noirs,' 'bazannez,' 'olivâtres') is reduced to three in English ('white,' 'black,' 'tawny'), with 'olivâtres' (olive-skinned) being omitted. This simplifies the enumeration by reducing descriptive detail.

The structured and repetitive French enumeration 'd'abord... & puis... & puis... & puis...' (first... and then... and then... and then...) is simplified to the less rigid and more varied sequence 'sometimes... sometimes... now... then...'. This makes the list flow more naturally but simplifies the formal enumerative structure.

The French construction 'tout cela mériteroit bien que l'on donnât vingt-quatre heures de son temps à le voir' (all that would well deserve that one give twenty-four hours of one's time to see it), which uses an impersonal pronoun 'l'on' and a subordinate clause, is simplified to the more concise passive construction 'twenty four hours would thus be very well bestow'd.'

The concise and slightly abstract French parenthetical phrase 'à le prendre dans l'air' (taking it/considering it in the air) is explicated and simplified into the more direct and easily understood clause 'but we will suppose our selves in the Air.'

chunks.sourceHtml:
P014: Copernic, luy répondis-je, ne le comprendroit pas mieux. D'abord il passera par icy des Anglois qui raisonneront peut-être de quelque dessein de Politique avec moins de gayeté que nous ne raisonnons de notre Philosophie; ensuite viendra une grànde Mer, & il se pourra trouver en ce lieu-là quelque Vaisseau qui n'y sera pas si à son aise que nous. Après cela paraîtront des Iroquois, qui mangeront tout vif quelque prisonnier de guerre, qui fera semblant de ne s'en pas soucier; des Femmes de la Terre de Jesso, qui n'employeront tout leur temps qu'à préparer le Repas de leurs Maris, & à se peindre de bleu les lévres & les sourcils pour plaire aux plus vilains Hommes du monde; des Tartares qui iront fort devotement en Pelerinage vers ce Grand Prêtre, qui ne sort jamais d'un lieu obseur, où il n'est éclairé que par des Lampes, à la lumière desquelles on l'adore; de belles Circassiennes qui ne feront aucune façon d'accorder tout au premier venu, hormis ce qu'elles croyent qui appartient essentiellement à leurs Maris; de petits Tartares qui iront voler des Femmes pour les Turcs & pour les Persans; enfin, nous qui debiterons peut-être encore des rêveries.

P015: Il est assez plaisant, dit la Marquise, d'imaginer ce que vous venez de me dire; mais si je voyois tout cela d'en haut, je voudrais avoir la liberté de hâter ou d'arrêter le mouvement de la Terre, selon que les objets me plairont plus ou moins, & je vous assure que je ferais passer bien vite ceux qui s'embarrassent de Politique, ou qui mangent leurs Ennemis; mais il y en a d'autres pour qui j'aurois de la curiosité. J'en aurais pour ces Belles Circassiennes, par exemple, elles ont un usage qui mr paroit assez particulier. C'est qu'elle sont si belles, luy dis-je, que leurs Maris trovent dans leurs faveurs un superflu qu'ils abandonnent aux Etrangers. Les Femmes de ces Païs icy sont donc bien laides aux prix d'elles, reprit la Marquise, car le Maris ne relâchent rien. Cela est cause qu'on prend davantage, repliqay-je, au lieu que...Taisez-vous, interrompit-elle, je ne veux plus dire de folies, aussi bien il me vient une difficulté sérieuse. Si la Terre tourne, nous changeons d'air à chaque moment, & nous respirons toûjours celuy d'un autre Païs. Nullement, Madame, répondis-je, l'air qui environne la Terre ne s'étend que jusqu'à une certaine hauteur, peut-être jusqu'à 20 lieües, il nous suit, & tourne avec nous. Vous avez veu mille fois l'ouvrage d'un Ver à soye, ou ces Coques que ces petits animaux travaillent avec tant d'art pour s'y emprisonner. Elles sont d'une soye fort serrée, mais elles sont couvertes d'un certain duvet fort leger & fort lâche. C'est ainsi que la Terre, qui est assez solide, est couverte depuis sa surface jusqu'à vinght lieües de hauteur tout au plus, d'une espèce de duvet, qui est l'air, & toute la Coque de Ver à soye tourne en même temps. Au-delà de l'air est la matiere celeste, incomparablement plus pure, plus subtile, & même plus agitée que luy.

P016: Vous me présentez la Terre sous des idées bien méprisables, dit la Marquise. C'est pourtant sur cette Coque de Ver à soye qu'il se fait de si grands Travaux, de si grandes Guerres, & qu'il règne de tous côtés une si grande agitation. Oüy, répondis-je, & pendant ce temps-là la Nature qui n'entre point en connaissance de tous ces petits mouvements particuliers, nous emporte tous ensemble d'un mouvement général, & se joüe de la petite boule.

P017: Il me semble, reprit-elle, qu'il est ridicule d'être sur quelque chose qui tourne, & de se tourmenter tant; mais le malheur est qu'on n'est pas assuré qu'on tourne; car enfin, à ne vous rien celer, toutes les précautions que vous prenez pour empêcher qu'on ne s'aperçoive du mouvement de la Terre, me sont suspectes. Est-il possible qu'il ne laissera pas quelque petite marque sensible à laquelle on le reconnaisse?
chunks.manualHtml: P008: Copernicus himself, said I, could not have comprehended it better: First then, we see some of our Neighbours passing by us, up to the Ears in Politicks, yet settling their Nation no better than we do the World in the Moon; then follows a great Sea, perhaps a Fleet of Ships, perhaps a Makrel-Boat, no matter whether; then come some of the Iroquois going to eat a Prisoner for their Breakfast, who seems as little concern'd as his Devourers: After appear the Women of the Land of Jesso, who spend all their time in dressing their Husbands Dinners and Suppers, and painting their Lips and Eye-brows blue, only to please the greatest Villains in the World: Then the fair Circassians, who are very free of their Favours, and grant all to the first Comer, except a little they reserve for their Husbands; then the Tartars going to steal Concubines for the Turks and Persians; and at last our own dear Countrymen, it may be in some points as ridiculous as the best of 'em. It is very pleasant, said the Countess, but to imagine what you tell me, tho' if I was above, and saw all this, I would have the Liberty to hasten or retard the motion of the Earth, according as the Objects pleas'd me more or less, and I assure you I should quickly send packing the Polititians and Maneaters, but should have a great curiosity for the Fair Circassians, for methinks they have a custom very particular. They are so extreamly Beautiful, said I, that their Husbands have enough, and to spare to a Stranger. I fear then, said she, the Women of our Country are very ugly, in respect of those Fair Ladies, for the Husbands part with nothing here, but keep all to themselves. 'Tis because they make more use, I reply'd, of-Hold your peace, said she, and no more of your Fooleries, I have a difficulty to clear, and you must be serious. As the Earth moves, the Air changeth every moment, so we breathe the Air of another Country: Not at all, I reply'd, for the Air which encompasseth the Earth, doth not extend above a certain height, perhaps 20 leagues it follows us and turns with us: Have you not seen the work of a Silk-Worm, the Shells which those little Animals imprison themselves in, and weave with so much Art; they are made of a Silk very close, but are covered with a Down very slack and soft: So the Earth which is solid, is covered from the surface 20 Leagues upwards, with a kind of Down, which is the Air, and all the Shell of the Silk-Worm turns at the same time: Beyond the Air is the Celestial Matter, incomparably more pure and subtile, and much more agitated than the Air: Your comparison, said, she, is somewhat mean, and yet what wonders are wrought, what Wars, what Changes in this little Shell? 'Tis true, I reply'd, but Nature takes no notice of such little particular Motions, but drives us along with the general motion, as if she were at Bouls. Methinks, said she, 'tis very ridiculous to be upon a thing that turns, and yet not be well assur'd that it doth turn; and to tell you the Truth, I begin to distrust the Reasons you give, why we should not be sensible of the Motion of the Earth; for is it possible there should not some little mark be left, by which we might perceive it?

explanations: The original's specific point about a single uncomfortable vessel ("quelque Vaisseau qui n'y sera pas si à son aise que nous") is simplified by replacing it with generalized examples of vessels and a colloquial dismissal ("no matter whether;"), losing the reflective nuance and simplifying the imagery.

The French "ce qu'elles croyent qui appartient essentiellement à leurs Maris" (that which they believe essentially belongs to their husbands), which involves belief and essence, is simplified to the more concrete "a little they reserve," using simpler vocabulary and reducing conceptual depth.
The adjective "petits" (small/young/lesser) modifying "Tartares" is omitted, simplifying the description by removing a modifying detail from the noun phrase.

The descriptive phrase "ceux qui s'embarrassent de Politique" (those who get entangled/involved in politics) is simplified into the single, more common noun "Polititians," making the text more concise and direct.

The descriptive phrase "ceux ... qui mangent leurs Ennemis" (those who eat their enemies) is simplified into the single noun "Maneaters," making the label more direct and using a common, albeit dramatic, term.

The somewhat analytical French "trovent dans leurs faveurs un superflu qu'ils abandonnent" (find in their favors a surplus that they abandon) is simplified by the more common and idiomatic English phrase "have enough, and to spare."

The French impersonal construction "il me vient une difficulté sérieuse" (a serious difficulty occurs to me/comes to me) is simplified to the more direct, active, and structurally simpler English phrase "I have a difficulty to clear."
The qualifying French adverb "assez" (rather/quite) in "assez solide" is omitted, simplifying "rather/quite solid" to the more absolute and direct "solid."

The French phrase "jusqu'à vinght lieües de hauteur tout au plus" (up to twenty leagues in height at the most) is simplified to the more concise "20 Leagues upwards," reducing descriptive length and complexity.

The complex French sentence "Vous me présentez la Terre sous des idées bien méprisables, dit la Marquise" (You present the Earth to me under very contemptible ideas) is simplified. The focus shifts from "ideas about the Earth" to "Your comparison," and the strong "bien méprisables" (very contemptible) is softened to "somewhat mean," reducing conceptual and emphatic complexity, as well as simplifying the overall sentence structure.

The vivid and specific French clause "qu'il règne de tous côtés une si grande agitation" (such great agitation reigns on all sides) is simplified and generalized to the single noun "Changes," losing the original's intensity, scope, and descriptive richness.

The formal French phrase "n'entre point en connaissance de" (does not take cognizance of / does not come to know) is simplified to the more common, direct, and less formal English phrasal verb "takes no notice of."

The phrase "et de se tourmenter tant" (and to torment oneself so much), which adds a layer of reflection on human folly to the Marquise's statement, is omitted. This simplifies her expressed thought by reducing its density and removing this particular philosophical observation.

The French "mais le malheur est que..." (but the misfortune/unhappiness is that...), which carries an emotional and philosophical weight, is simplified by rephrasing and integrating the idea of uncertainty more directly ("and yet not be well assur'd..."), making the expression more straightforward and lessening the explicit emphasis on "misfortune."

The French phrase "toutes les précautions que vous prenez pour empêcher qu'on ne s'aperçoive du mouvement de la Terre" (all the precautions you take to prevent one from perceiving the Earth's movement) is simplified to "the Reasons you give, why we should not be sensible of the Motion of the Earth." This changes the focus from the philosopher's complex explanatory actions (precautions to prevent perception) to the simpler concept of "Reasons," using more common vocabulary and a more direct conceptualization.

chunks.sourceHtml: P018: Les mouvements les plus naturels, répondis-je, & les plus ordinaires, sont ceux qui se font le moins sentir, & cela est vray jusque dans la Morale. Le mouvement de l'Amour propre nous est si naturel, que le plus souvent nous ne le sentons pas, & que nous croyons agir par d'autres principes. Ah! vous moralisez, dit- elle, quand il est question de Physique, cela s'appelle bâiller. Retirons-nous, aussi bien en voilà assez pour la premiere fois. Demain nous reviendrons icy, vous avec vos Systêmes, & moi avec mon Ignorance.
chunks.manualHtml: P009: All Motions, said I, the more common and Natural they are, are the less perceptible, and this holds true even in Morality; the motion of self Love is so natural to us, that for the most part we are not sensible of it, and we believe we act by other Principles: You are Moralizing, said she, to a question of Natural Philosophy: But 'tis enough for the first time, let us now go home, and meet here again to Morrow; you with your Systemes, and I with my ignorance.
chunks.aiHtml: P009: All Motions, said I, the more common and Natural they are, are the less perceptible, and this holds true even in Morality; the motion of self Love is so natural to us, that for the most part we are not sensible of it, and we believe we act by other Principles: You are Moralizing, said she, to a question of Natural Philosophy: But 'tis enough for the first time, let us now go home, and meet here again to Morrow; you with your Systemes, and I with my ignorance.
explanations: The French phrase "cela s'appelle bâiller" (literally "that is called yawning," implying it's boring or evasive), which concludes the Marquise's observation about moralizing during a physics discussion, is entirely omitted in the English translation. This omission simplifies the Marquise's speech by removing an idiomatic and witty criticism. As a result, stylistic richness, a piece of cultural nuance in expression, and the sharpness of her character's retort are reduced. The target segment only renders the first part of the French clause, lacking the pointed concluding remark.

The French "Retirons-nous," (Let's withdraw/retire) is translated using the more common and concrete phrase "let us now go home,". While conveying the general intent of departure, "go home" is simpler and more specific than a more literal translation like "let us withdraw," which could be perceived as more formal or less direct. This choice simplifies the vocabulary and makes the Marquise's suggestion very straightforward.

chunks.sourceHtml: P019: En retournant au Château je luy dis pour épuiser la matiere des Systêmes, qu'il y en avoit un troisiéme inventé par Tycho Brahé qui, voulant absolument que la Terre fût immobile, la plaçoit au centre du Monde, & faisoit tourner autour d'elle le Soleil, autour duquel tournoient toutes les autres Planètes, parce que depuis les nouvelles Découvertes, il n'y avoit pas moyen de faire tourner les Planètes autour de la Terre. Mais la Marquise, qui a le discernement vif & prompt, jugea qu'il y avoit trop d'affectation à exempter la Terre de tourner autour du Soleil, puisqu'on n'en pouvait pas exempter tant d'autres grands corps; que le Soleil n'étoit plus si propre à tourner autour de la Terre, depuis que toutes les Planètes tournaient autour de luy; que ce systême ne pouvoit être propre tout au plus qu'à soûtenir l'Immobilité de la Terre, quand on avoit bien envie de la soûtenir, & nullement à la persuader; & enfin il fut résolu que nous nous en tiendrions à celuy de Copernic, qui est plus uniforme & plus riant, & n'a aucun mélange de préjugé. En effet la simplicité dont il est, vous persuade, & sa hardiesse vous fait plaisir.
chunks.manualHtml: P010: In returning back to the Castle, that I might say all I could on the Subject, I told her of a third Systeme, invented by Ticho Brahe, who had fix'd the Earth in the Centre of the World, turn'd the Sun round the Earth, and the rest of the Planets round the Sun; for since the new discoveries, there was no way left to have the Planets turn round the Earth. But the Countess, who had a quick apprehension, said, she thought it was too affected, among so many great Bodies, to exempt the Earth only from turning round the Sun; that it was improper to make the Sun turn round the Earth, when all the Planets turn round the Sun; and that tho' this Systeme was to prove the immobility of the Earth, yet she thought it very improbable: So we resolv'd to stick to Copernicus, whose opinion we thought most Uniform, Probable, and Diverting.
chunks.aiHtml: P010: In returning back to the Castle, that I might say all I could on the Subject, I told her of a third Systeme, invented by Ticho Brahe, who had fix'd the Earth in the Centre of the World, turn'd the Sun round the Earth, and the rest of the Planets round the Sun; for since the new discoveries, there was no way left to have the Planets turn round the Earth. But the Countess, who had a quick apprehension, said, she thought it was too affected, among so many great Bodies, to exempt the Earth only from turning round the Sun; that it was improper to make the Sun turn round the Earth, when all the Planets turn round the Sun; and that tho' this Systeme was to prove the immobility of the Earth, yet she thought it very improbable: So we resolv'd to stick to Copernicus, whose opinion we thought most Uniform, Probable, and Diverting.
explanations: The French phrase "voulant absolument que la Terre fût immobile" (absolutely wanting/insisting the Earth to be immobile) emphasizes Tycho Brahe's strong motivation. The English translation "who had fix'd the Earth" simplifies this by stating a characteristic of his system, making the phrasing more direct and removing the nuance of his insistence.

The French original offers a detailed and nuanced critique: the system was, at best, only suitable for *supporting* the Earth's immobility (particularly if one strongly *wished* to support it) but not for *persuading* anyone of it. The English translation simplifies this significantly to "tho' this Systeme was to prove the immobility of the Earth, yet she thought it very improbable," condensing the argument, reducing its length, and omitting the finer points about its conditional utility and lack of persuasive power.

The French description of Copernicus's system includes the phrase "& n'a aucun mélange de préjugé" (and has no mixture of prejudice/bias). This specific positive attribute is omitted in the English translation, which concludes its description with "Diverting." This omission simplifies the characterization by removing an important philosophical commendation, thereby reducing textual density.

The entire final sentence of the French paragraph, "En effet la simplicité dont il est, vous persuade, & sa hardiesse vous fait plaisir." (Indeed, its simplicity persuades you, and its boldness pleases you.), is omitted in the English translation. The English paragraph concludes with the description of Copernicus's opinion, lacking this subsequent reflective statement. This omission significantly simplifies the text by reducing its length and removing a philosophical conclusion.

The French phrase "qui a le discernement vif & prompt" (who has sharp and quick discernment) uses more elaborate and specific vocabulary. The English translation "who had a quick apprehension" simplifies this by using the more general term "apprehension" (for understanding) and the single adjective "quick," reducing the descriptive richness and formality of the original.

The French verb "jugea" (judged) conveys a firm and considered assessment. The English translation "said, she thought" simplifies this by using a more common, conversational, and less decisive phrasal construction, thereby softening the force of the Marquise's conclusion and simplifying the sentence structure.

chunks.sourceHtml: P020: SECOND SOIR. Que la Lune est une Terre habitée.
chunks.manualHtml: P011: The Second Evening.
chunks.aiHtml: P011: The Second Evening.
explanations: The English translation simplifies the original French chapter heading by omitting the entire descriptive subtitle, 'Que la Lune est une Terre habitée' (That the Moon is an inhabited Earth). This omission significantly reduces the length and informational density of the heading. While the French original immediately presents a key, speculative theme of the chapter, the English version offers only a neutral structural marker ('The Second Evening'), thereby simplifying the introduction to the chapter's content and reducing its initial provocative impact.

chunks.sourceHtml: P021: Le lendemain au matin dès que l'on pût entrer dans l'Appartement de la Marquise, j'envoyai savoir de ses nouvelles, & lui demander si elle avoit pû dormir en tournant. Elle me fit répondre qu'elle etoit déjà toute accoûtumée à cette allûre de la Terre, & qu'elle avoit passé la nuit aussi tranquillement qu'auroit pû faire Copernic lui-même. Quelque temps après il vint chez elle du monde qui y demeura jusqu'au soir, selon l'ennuyeuse coutume de la Campagne. Encore leur fut-on bien obligé, car la Campagne leur donnoit aussi le droit de pousser leur visite jusqu'au lendemain, s'ils eussent voulu, & ils eurent l'honnêteté de ne le pas faire. Ainsi la Marquise & moi nous nous retrouvâmes libres le Soir. Nous allâmes encore dans le Parc, & la conversation ne manqua pas de tourner aussitôt sur nos Sistêmes. Elle les avoit si bien conceus, qu'elle dédaigna d'en parler une seconde fois, & elle voulut que je la menasse a quelque chose de nouveau. Et bien donc, luy dis-je, puisque le Soleil, qui est présentement immobile, a cessé d'être Planète, & que la Terre qui se meut autour de lui, a commencé d'en être une, vous ne serez pas si surprise d'entendre dire que la Lune est une Terre comme celle-cy, & qu'apparemment elle est habitée. Je n'ay pourtant jamais oüy parler de la Lune habitée, dit-elle, que comme d'une folie & d'une vision. C'en est peut-être une aussi, répondis-je. Je ne prens parti dans ces choses-là que comme on en prend dans les Guerres Civiles, où l'incertitude de ce qui peut arriver, fait qu'on entretient toûjours des intelligences dans le party opposé, & qu'on a des ménagemens avec ses Ennemis mêmes. Pour moi, quoyque je voye la Lune habitée, je ne laisse pas de vivre civilement avec ceux qui ne le croyent pas, — & je me tiens toujours en état de me pouvoir ranger à leur opinion avec honneur, si elle avoit le dessus; mais en attendant qu'ils ayent sur nous quelque avantage considérable, voyci ce qui m'a mis du côté des Habitans de la Lune.
chunks.manualHtml: P012: IN the Morning, I sent to the Countess's Apartment, to know how she had rested, and whether the Motion of the Earth had not disturb'd her? she answer'd, she began to be accustom'd to it, and that she had slept as well as Copernicus himself: Soon after there came some Neighbours to dine with her, but they went away in the Evening; so that after Supper we walk'd again into the Park, and immediately fell upon our Systemes. She so well conceiv'd what I told her the night before, that she desir'd I would proceed without any repetition. Well, Madam, said I, Since the Sun, which is now immoveable, hath left off being a Planet; and the Earth, which turns round him, is now become one, you will not be surprized when you hear that the Moon is an Earth too, and that she is inhabited as ours is. I confess, said she, I have often heard talk of the World in the Moon, but I always look'd upon it as Visionary and meer Fancy. And it may be so still, said I. I am in this case as People in a Civil War, where the uncertainty of what may happen makes 'em hold intelligence with the opposite Party; for tho' I verily believe the Moon is inhabited, I live civilly vvith those who do not believe it; and I am (as some honest Gentlemen in point of Religion) still ready to embrace the prevailing Opinion, but till the Unbelievers have a more considerable Advantage, I am for the People in the Moon.

I confess, said she, I have often heard talk of the World in the Moon, but I always look'd upon it as Visionary and meer Fancy. And it may be so still, said I. I am in this case as People in a Civil War, where the uncertainty of what may happen makes 'em hold intelligence with the opposite Party; for tho' I verily believe the Moon is inhabited, I live civilly vvith those who do not believe it; and I am (as some honest Gentlemen in point of Religion) still ready to embrace the prevailing Opinion, but till the Unbelievers have a more considerable Advantage, I am for the People in the Moon.
explanations: The French phrase 'Le lendemain au matin dès que l'on pût entrer' (The next day in the morning as soon as one could enter) is reduced to 'IN the Morning,' omitting the detail of when entry was possible. Additionally, the concise and allusive 'si elle avoit pû dormir en tournant' (if she had been able to sleep while turning) is rephrased more explicitly as 'whether the Motion of the Earth had not disturb'd her?', simplifying by making the implied cause explicit.

The French 'Elle me fit répondre' (She had someone answer for her) is simplified to 'she answer'd,' removing the social nuance of indirect communication. Also, the emphatic 'déjà toute accoûtumée à cette allûre de la Terre' (already completely accustomed to this gait/pace of the Earth) is reduced to the less forceful and less specific 'she began to be accustom'd to it.'

The translation significantly simplifies this passage by omitting the subjective commentary 'selon l'ennuyeuse coutume de la Campagne' (according to the tedious custom of the countryside). More substantially, the entire following sentence, 'Encore leur fut-on bien obligé, car la Campagne leur donnoit aussi le droit de pousser leur visite jusqu'au lendemain, s'ils eussent voulu, & ils eurent l'honnêteté de ne le pas faire,' which provides social commentary and irony, is omitted. This reduces text length and satirical nuance.

The French 'la conversation ne manqua pas de tourner aussitôt sur nos Sistêmes' (the conversation did not fail to turn immediately to our Systems) uses a more formal litotes (double negative). The English 'and immediately fell upon our Systemes' simplifies this to a more direct and somewhat more colloquial affirmative phrasing.

The French 'Elle les avoit si bien conceus' is made more explicit by adding 'what I told her the night before.' More significantly, the two distinct clauses 'qu'elle dédaigna d'en parler une seconde fois' (that she disdained to speak of it a second time) and 'elle voulut que je la menasse a quelque chose de nouveau' (she wanted me to lead her to something new) are condensed and rephrased. The strong verb 'dédaigna' (disdained) is softened to 'desir'd,' and the evocative 'menasse a quelque chose de nouveau' is simplified to the more functional 'proceed without any repetition,' reducing stylistic complexity and the force of the Marquise's expression.

The French 'comme celle-cy' (like this one [the Earth]), referring to the Moon being an Earth, is simplified to 'too.' Furthermore, the idea that the Moon is inhabited like Earth is made more explicit by adding 'as ours is,' which is an expansion for clarity based on the implicit comparison in 'comme celle-cy' but simplifies the reader's inferential work.

The French phrase 'une folie' (a madness/folly), indicating a strong dismissal, is simplified to the less intense 'meer Fancy.' The specific term 'Lune habitée' (inhabited Moon) is rendered as 'the World in the Moon,' using a more common, perhaps more readily understood, English idiom for the concept.

The original French describes two consequences of uncertainty in civil wars: maintaining intelligence with the opposition, AND '& qu'on a des ménagemens avec ses Ennemis mêmes' (and that one manages relations carefully even with one's Enemies / shows consideration for one's very Enemies). This second clause, detailing a specific sophisticated behavior of 'ménagemens' (diplomatic handling), is omitted in the English translation's account of the civil war analogy, simplifying the description by reducing its complexity and nuance.

The French metaphorical 'quoyque je voye la Lune habitée' (although I see the Moon inhabited) is translated with the more direct and less figurative 'tho' I verily believe the Moon is inhabited.' Additionally, the French litotes 'je ne laisse pas de vivre civilement' (I do not fail to live civilly / I nevertheless live civilly) is simplified to the direct affirmative statement 'I live civilly,' making the sentence structure more straightforward.

The elaborate French phrasing '& je me tiens toujours en état de me pouvoir ranger à leur opinion avec honneur, si elle avoit le dessus;' (and I always keep myself in a state/position to be able to rally to their opinion with honor, if it gained the upper hand) is simplified. The English 'and I am... still ready to embrace the prevailing Opinion,' uses more direct vocabulary and structure. The specific notion of maintaining one's position 'avec honneur' (with honor) is omitted, reducing a layer of personal justification.

The French sentence concludes with 'voyci ce qui m'a mis du côté des Habitans de la Lune' (here is what has put me on the side of the Inhabitants of the Moon), a rhetorical construction that signals an upcoming explanation. The English translation simplifies this to a direct statement of current allegiance: 'I am for the People in the Moon,' omitting the forward-pointing element and thus simplifying the sentence's rhetorical structure and reducing its length.

chunks.sourceHtml:
P022: Suposons qu'il n'y ait jamais eu nul commerce entre Paris & Saint-Denis, & qu'un Bourgeois de Paris, qui ne sera jamais sorty de sa Ville, soit sur les Tours de Notre Dame, & voye Saint-Denis de loin; on luy demandera s'il croit que Saint-Denis soit habité comme Paris. Il répondra hardiment que non; car, dira- t-il, je vois bien les Habitans de Paris, mais ceux de Saint-Denis je ne les voy point, & on n'en a jamais entendu parler. Il y aura quelqu'un qui luy representera qu'à la vérité quand on est sur les Tours de Notre-Dame, on ne voit pas les Habitans de Saint-Denis, mais que l'éloignement en est cause; que tout ce qu'on peut voir de Saint-Denis ressemble fort à Paris, que Saint Denis a des Clochers, des Maisons, des Murailles, & qu'il pourrait bien encore ressembler à Paris pour ce qui est d'être habité. Tout cela ne gagnera rien sur mon Bourgeois, il s'obstinera toûjours à soûtenir que Saint-Denis n'est point habité, puisqu'il n'y voit personne. Notre Saint-Denis c'est la Lune, & chacun de nous est ce Bourgeois de Paris, qui n'est jamais sorty de sa Ville.

P023: Ah! interrompit la Marquise, vous nous faites tort, nous ne sommes point si sots que votre Bourgeois. Puis qu'il voit que Saint-Denis est tout fait comme Paris, il faut qu'il ait perdu la raison pour ne le pas croire habité; mais la Lune n'est point du tout faite comme la Terre. Prenez garde, Madame, repris-je, car s'il faut que la Lune ressemble en tout à la Terre, vous voilà dans l'obligation de croire la Lune habitée. J'avoüe, répondit-elle, qu'il n'y aura pas moyen de s'en dispenser, & je vous vois un air de confiance qui me fait déjà peur. Les deux mouvements de la Terre, dont je ne me fusse jamais doutée, me rendent timide sur tout le reste; mais pourtant seroit-il bien possible que la Terre fût lumineuse comme la Lune? Car il faut cela pour leur ressemblance. Hélas! Madame, répliquay-je, être lumineux n'est pas si grand-chose que vous pensez. Il n'y a que le Soleil en qui cela soit une qualité considérable. Il est lumineux par luy- même, & en vertu d'une nature particulière qu'il a; mais les Planètes n'éclairent que parce qu'elles sont éclairées de luy. Il envoye sa lumière à la Lune, elle nous la renvoye, & il faut que la Terre renvoye aussi à la Lune la lumière du Soleil; il n'y a pas plus loin de la Terre à la Lune, que de la Lune à la Terre.

P024: Mais, dit la Marquise, la Terre est-elle aussi propre que la Lune à renvoyer la lumiere du Soleil? Je vous vois toûjours, pour la Lune, repris-je, un reste d'estime dont vous ne sauriez vous défaire. La lumiere est composée de petites balles qui bondissent sur ce qui est solide, & retournent d'un autre côté, au lieu qu'elles passent au travers de ce qui leur presente des ouvertures en ligne droite, comme l'air ou le verre. Ainsi ce qui fait que la Lune nous éclaire, c'est qu'elle est un Corps dur & solide, qui nous renvoye ces petites balles. Or je croy que vous ne contesterez pas à la Terre cette même dureté e& cette même solidité. Admirez donc ce que c'est que d'être posté avantageusement. Parce que la Lune est éloignée de nous, nous ne la voyons que comme un Corps lumineux, & nous ignorons que ce soit une grosse masse, toute semblable à la Terre. Au contraire, parce que la Terre a le malheur que nous la voyons de trop prés, elle ne nous paroît qu'une grosse masse, propre seulement à fournir de la pâture aux Animaux, & nous ne nous apercevons pas qu'elle est lumineuse, faute de nous pouvoir mettre à quelque distance d'elle. Cela va de la même maniere, dit la Marquise, que quand nous sommes frapés de l'éclat des Conditions; élevées au-dessus des nôtres, & que nous ne voyons pas, qu'au fond elles se ressemblent toutes extrêmement.

P025: C'est la même chose, répondis-je. Nous voulons juger de tout, & nous sommes toûjours dans un mauvais point de veüe. Nous voulons juger de nous, nous en sommes trop près; nous voulons juger des autres, nous en sommes trop loin. Qui serait entre la Lune & la Terre, ce seroit la vraye place pour les bien voir. Il faudroit être simplement spectateur du Monde, & non pas Habitant. Je ne me consoleray jamais, dit-elle, de l'injustice que nous faisons à la Terre, & de la préoccupation trop favorable où nous sommes pour la Lune, si vous ne m'assurez que les Gens de la Lune ne connaissent pas mieux leurs avantages que nous connoissons les nôtres, & qu'ils prennent notre Terre pour un Astre, sans savoir que leur habitation en est un aussi. Pour cela, repris-je, je vous le garantis. Nous leur paraissons faire assez regulièrement nos fonctions d'Astres. Il est vray qu'ils ne nous voyent pas décrire un Cercle autour d'eux; mais il n'importe, voicy ce que c'est. La moitié de la Lune qui se trouva tournée vers nous au commencement du Monde, y a toûjours eté tournée depuis; elle ne nous présente jamais que ces yeux, cette bouche, & le reste de ce visage que notre imagination luy compose sur le fondement des tâches qu'elle nous montre. Si l'autre moitié opposée se presentoit à nous, d'autres tâches differemment arrangées, nous feroient sans doute imaginer quelque autre figure. Ce n'est pas que la Lune ne tourne sur elle-même, elle y tourne en autant de temps qu'autour de la Terre, c'est à dire, en un mois; mais lors qu'elle fait une partie de ce tremblement, & de s'imaginer que nous avons dans le Ciel comme un mouvement de Pendule qui va & vient.
chunks.manualHtml:
P013: Suppose there had never been any Communication between London and Greenwich, and a Cockney, who was never beyond the Walls of London, saw Greenwich from the top of the Pyramid; you ask him if he believes Greenwich is inhabited as London is? He presently answers, No; for, saith he, I see People at London, but none at Greenwich; nor did I ever hear of any there: 'Tis true, you tell him, that from the Pyramid he cannot perceive any Inhabitants at Greenwich, because of the distance; but all that he doth discover of Greenwich very much resembleth what he sees at London, the Steeples, Houses, Walls; so that it may very well be inhabited as London is; all this signifies nothing, my Cockney still persists Greenwich is not inhabited, because he sees no body there. The Moon is our Greenwich, and every one of us as meer Cockneys as he that never was out of the sound of Bow-Bell. You are too severe, said she, upon your Fellow-Citizens; we are not all sure so silly as your Cockney; since Greenwich is just as London is, he is a Fool if he doth not think it inhabited: But the Moon is not at all like the Earth. Have a care what you say, I reply'd, for if the Moon resembleth the Earth, you are under a necessity to believe it inhabited. If it be so, said she, I own I cannot be dispens'd from believing it, and you seem so confident of it, that I fear I must, whether I will or no. 'Tis true, the two Motions of the Earth (which I could never imagine till now) do a little stagger me as to all the rest: But yet how is it possible the Earth should enlighten as the Moon doth, without which they cannot be alike? If that be all, said I, the difference is not great, for 'tis the Sun which is the sole Fountain of Light; that Quality proceeds only from him, and if the Planets give Light to us, it is because they first receive it from the Sun; the Sun sends Light to the Moon, and she reflects it back on the Earth; the Earth in the same manner receives Light from the Sun, and sends it to the Moon; for the Distance is the same between the Earth and the Moon, as between the Moon and the Earth. But is the Earth, said the Countess, as fit to send back the Light of the Sun as the Moon is? You are altogether for the Moon, said I, she is much oblig'd to you; but you must know that Light is made up of certain little Balls, which rebound from what is solid, but pass through what admits of an entrance in a right Line, as Air or Glass: So that, that which makes the Moon enlighten us, is that she is a Firm and Solid Body, from which the little Balls rebound; and we must deny our Senses, if we will not allow the Earth the same Solidity; in short, the Difference is how we are seated, for the Moon being at so vast a Distance from us, we can only discover her to be a Body of Light, and do not perceive that she is a great Masse, altogether like the Earth: Whereas on the contrary, because we are so near the Earth, we know her to be a great Masse, but do not discover her to be a Body of Light, for want of the due distance: It is just so with us all, said the Countess, we are dazled with the Quality and Fortune of those who are above us, when, do but look to the Bottom, and we are all alike.

P020: Fear it not Madam, said I; do you think we are the only Fools of the Universe? Is it not consistent with Ignorance to spread it self every where? 'Tis true, we can only guess at the Folly of the People in the Moon, but I no more doubt it, than I do the most authentick News that comes from thence. What News comes from thence, said she? That which the Learned bring us, I reply'd, who travel thither every day with their Tubes and Tellescopes: they will tell you of their Discoveries there, of Lands, Seas, Lakes, high Mountains, and deep Abysses.

explanations: Simplifies sentence structure by replacing an impersonal, complex construction ('Il y aura quelqu'un qui luy representera que...' / 'There will be someone who will point out to him that...') with a direct attribution to 'you' ('you tell him'), making the narrative more immediate and less layered.

The French modal construction 'il faut qu'il ait perdu la raison' (it is necessary that he has lost his reason / he must have lost his reason) is simplified to a more direct conditional statement 'he is a Fool if...', which also employs more common vocabulary ('Fool').
Simplifies by omitting the qualifying phrase 'en tout' (in everything / in all respects) from the condition, thereby reducing the specificity and emphasis of the original French statement.

Simplifies by replacing the French literary past subjunctive 'dont je ne me fusse jamais doutée' (of which I would never have suspected) with the more common and structurally simpler English past modal construction 'which I could never imagine'.

The French modal of necessity 'il faut que la Terre renvoye aussi...' (it is necessary that the Earth also send back...) is removed, simplifying the sentence to a direct declarative statement about the Earth's actions without the explicit expression of necessity.

The nuanced French phrase 'un reste d'estime dont vous ne sauriez vous défaire' (a remnant of esteem which you cannot manage to rid yourself of) is simplified to the more direct, colloquial, and less psychologically detailed statement 'You are altogether for the Moon,' reducing its stylistic complexity.

The rhetorical imperative and somewhat formal phrasing 'Admirez donc ce que c'est que d'être posté avantageusement' (Admire then what it is to be advantageously positioned) is simplified to a concise summary 'in short, the Difference is how we are seated,' using more common and less elaborate phrasing.

Simplifies by removing the figurative personification 'la Terre a le malheur que...' (the Earth has the misfortune that...), rendering the cause-effect statement more direct and less stylistically rich.

Simplifies by omitting the illustrative detail 'propre seulement à fournir de la pâture aux Animaux' (suitable only for providing pasture/food to Animals), which reduces the descriptive richness and specificity of the original text.

The French sentence structure involving a subordinate clause of comparison ('que quand nous sommes frapés... & que nous ne voyons pas, qu'au fond...') is simplified into a more direct structure with an imperative ('do but look to the Bottom') followed by a concise, generalized statement ('and we are all alike'), which is also simpler than 'elles se ressemblent toutes extrêmement'.

The impersonal French conditional 'Il faudroit être' (It would be necessary to be / One would have to be) is simplified to a direct infinitive phrase 'to be', streamlining the sentence structure by removing the modal verb construction.

Simplifies vocabulary by using the more common word 'opinion' instead of 'préoccupation,' where the French 'préoccupation' (preoccupation / preconceived notion / bias) carries a more complex semantic load than the simpler 'opinion' in this context.

Simplifies by omitting the conversational transitional phrase 'voicy ce que c'est' (here is what it is / here's the thing), which serves in French to introduce an explanation. Its removal makes the text slightly more abrupt by reducing this connective element.

Simplifies the French construction 'elle ne nous présente jamais que X... sur le fondement des tâches Y' (it never presents to us but X... on the basis of the spots Y) to a more straightforward English phrasing 'X... are still the same,' using 'of the Spots' which is simpler than 'sur le fondement des tâches'. Also, 'qui se trouva tournée' (which found itself turned) is simplified to 'which was turn'd'.

chunks.sourceHtml: P026: Toutes ces Planètes, dit la Marquise, sont faites comme nous, qui rejetons toûjours sur les autres ce qui est en nous-mêmes. La Terre dit: Ce n'est pas moy qui tourne, c'est le Soleil. La Lune dit, _Ce n'est pas moy qui tremble, c'est la Terre. Il y a bien de l'erreur par tout. Je ne vous conseille pas d'entreprendre d'y rien réformer, répondis-je, il vaut mieux que vous acheviez de vous convaincre de l'entiere ressemblance de la Terre & de la Lune. Représentez-vous ces deux grandes Boules suspendües dans les Cieux. Vous savez que le Soleil éclaire toûjours une moitié des Corps qui sont ronds, & que l'autre moitié est dans l'ombre. Il y a donc toûjours une moitié, tant de la Terre que de la Lune, qui est éclairée du Soleil, c'est à dire, qui a le jour, & une autre moitié qui est dans la nuit. Remarquez d'ailleurs que comme une Balle a moins de force & de vitesse après qu'elle a été donner contre une muraille qui l'a renvoyée d'un autre côté, de même la lumière s'affoiblit lors qu'elle a été réfléchie par quelque Corps. Cette lumière blanchâtre qui nous vient de la Lune, est la lumière même du Soleil, mais elle ne peut venir de la Lune à nous que par une réflexion. Elle a donc beaucoup perdu de la force & de la vivacité qu'elle avoit lorsqu'elle étoit receüe directement sur la Lune, & cette lumière éclatante que nous recevons du Soleil & que la Terre reflechit sur la Lune, ne doit plus être qu'une lumiere blanchâtre quand elle y est arrivée. Ainsi ce qui nous paroit lumineux dans la Lune, & qui nous éclaire pendant nos nuits, ce sont des parties de la Lune qui ont le jour; & les parties de la Terre qui ont le jour lors qu'elles sont tournées vers les parties de la Lune qui ont la nuit les éclairent aussi. Tout dépend de la manière dont la Lune & la Terre se regardent. Dans les premiers jours du mois que l'on ne voit pas la Lune, c'est qu'elle est entre le Soleil & nous, & qu'elle marche de jour avec le Soleil. Il faut necessairement que toute sa moitié qui a le jour, soit tournée vers le Soleil, & que toute sa moitié qui a la nuit, soit tournée vers nous. Nous n'avons garde de voir cette moitié qui n'a aucune lumière pour se faire voir. Mais cette moitié de la Lune qui a la nuit, étant tournée vers la moitié de la Terre qui a le jour, nous voit sans être veüe, & nous voit sous la même figure que nous voyons la Pleine Lune. C'est alors pour les Gens de la Lune Pleine Terre, s'il est permis de parler ainsi. Ensuite la Lune qui avance sur son Cercle d'un mois, se dégage de dessous le Soleil, & commence à tourner vers nous un petit coin de sa moitié éclairée, & voilà le Croissant. Alors aussi les parties de la Lune qui ont la nuit commencent à ne plus voir toute la moitié de la Terre qui a le jour, & nous sommes en Décours pour elles.
chunks.manualHtml: P015: I find, saith the Countess, the Planets are just like us; we cast that upon others which is in our selves; the Earth saith, 'Tis not I that turn, 'tis the Sun; the Moon saith, 'tis not I that shake, 'tis the Earth; there is a great deal of errour every where. But I would not advise you, said I, to undertake the reforming it; you had better convince your self of the entire resemblance of the Earth and the Moon: Imagine then these two great Bowls held up in the Heavens, you know that the Sun always enlightens the one half of a Body that is round, and the other half is in the Shadow; there is then one half of the Earth and one half of the Moon which is enlightned by the Sun; that is, which hath Day, and the other half which is Night. Observe also, that as a Ball hath less force after it hath been struck against a Wall which sends it to the other side, so Light is weakned when it is reflected. This pale Light which comes to us from the Moon, is the very Light of the Sun, but it cannot come to us from the Moon but by reflection; it hath lost much of the Force and Lustre it had when it came directly from the Sun upon the Moon; and that bright Light which shines directly upon us from the Sun, and which the Earth reflects upon the Moon, is as pale and weak when it arrives there; so that the Light which appears to us in the Moon, and which enlightens our Nights, is the parts of the Moon which have Day, and that part of the Earth which hath Day, when it is opposite to the part of the Moon which hath Night, gives Light to it: All depends upon how the Moon and the Earth behold one another. At the beginning of the Month we do not see the Moon, because she is between the Sun and us; that half of her which hath Day, is then turn'd towards the Sun, and that half which hath Night, turn'd towards us; we cannot see it then, because it hath no Light upon it; but that half of the Moon which hath Night, being turn'd to the half of the Earth which hath Day, sees us without being perceiv'd, and we then appear to them just as the full Moon doth to us; so that, as I may say, the People of the Moon have then a full Earth; but the Moon being advanc'd upon her Circle of a Month, comes from under the Sun, and begins to turn towards us a little corner of the half which is Light, there's the Crescent; then those parts of the Moon which have Night do not see all the half of the Earth which hath Day, and we are then in the Wayn to them.
