explanations: The more formal French phrase 'quand on voudra se donner la peine de les aller voir' (when one wants to take the trouble to go see them) is simplified into the colloquial 'when we have a mind to't' and the reductive ''tis no more but going to see 'em,' lowering formality and complexity.

The original French includes the content of the 'serious answer' ('qu'on ne sait ce qui arrivera' - that one doesn't know what will happen) as part of the philosopher's hypothetical statement. The English translation omits this subordinate clause, simplifying the sentence structure by making the initial statement more direct and less detailed.

The translation omits the philosopher's introspective clauses describing his 'ridiculous thought': 'qui a un air de vraisemblance qui me surprend, je ne say où elle peut l'avoir pris, étant aussi impertinente qu'elle est' (which has an air of plausibility that surprises me, I don't know where it could have gotten it from, being as impertinent as it is). This reduces the density and nuance of the original, simplifying the characterization of his idea.

The French text distinguishes between lack of knowledge of 'Sciences' and 'les Arts les plus simples, & les plus necessaires' (the simplest and most necessary Arts). The English 'they knew nothing at all of Arts or Sciences,' simplifies by collapsing these into a single, broader statement, losing the specific emphasis on basic practical arts.

The translation omits the introductory phrase 'à proprement parler' (properly speaking), simplifying the sentence by removing a nuanced, conversational marker. The meaning of the following clause is also altered, but the omission of this specific phrase is a reduction of textual complexity.

The French phrase 'de tel côté & de tel sens qu'on vouloit' (in whichever direction and in whichever way one wanted) offers a more detailed description of navigational control. The English 'that they might easily pass over that infinite Space of Water,' simplifies this by being less specific about the manner of control, making the phrasing more general.

The French 'qu'on s'y pouvoit arrêter sans mouvement au milieu des Flots émeus' (that one could stop there without movement in the midst of agitated Waves) is simplified to 'that they might stop in the middle of the Waves.' The descriptive details 'sans mouvement' (without movement) and 'Flots émeus' (agitated waves) are omitted, reducing the vividness and richness of the imagery for conciseness.

The French 'Je ne sais, Madame, si vous entrez comme moy, dans la surprise des Américains' (I don't know, Madam, if you share with me in the surprise of the Americans) is a polite, hesitant inquiry. The English 'Do but consider, Madam, the surprize of the Americans,' simplifies this into a direct imperative, removing the nuance of the philosopher gauging the Marquise's reaction and making the statement more assertive.

The French 'je ne veux plus jurer qu'il ne puisse y avoir...' (I no longer want to swear that there cannot be...) is a personal declaration. The English changes this to an impersonal rhetorical question 'shall any one say there shall never be...'. This alteration simplifies by shifting from a subjective statement of personal conviction to a generalized challenge, reducing focus on the philosopher's internal thought process.

The French modal construction 'eût dû avoir' (ought to have been / was supposed to be) implies a sense of predetermined possibility. The English 'would ever be any' simplifies this by removing the specific modal nuance of 'dû' (ought to), making the proposition more general.

The philosopher's witty interjection 'Qui vous dit le contraire, répondis-je?' and the Marquise's subsequent 'Mais je veux vous le prouver... l'aveu que vous en faites' are entirely omitted in the translation. This simplifies the dialogue by removing a rapid, character-revealing exchange, thus shortening the interaction and reducing its playful complexity. (The target segment is empty as the text is omitted).

The French 'De ces planches là il y avoit bien loin jusqu'à de gros Navires...' (From those planks, it was a long way to large ships...) uses a metaphor of distance for development. The English 'there were no Vessels then thought of to sail round the World,' simplifies this by replacing the metaphorical expression with a more direct statement about the absence of advanced vessels, making the concept less figurative.

The French text poses a rhetorical question: 'Pretendons-nous...?' (Do we pretend...?). The English translation changes this into a declarative statement: 'We do not yet pretend...'. This alteration simplifies the original by removing the interrogative form, making the assertion more direct and less Socratic.

The French 'Je ne consentiray point... qu'on vôle jamais, que d'une maniere à se rompre aussi tôt le cou' conveys sarcastic agreement (she'll only agree if it means breaking necks). The English 'I can never believe you will fly, but you must endanger your Neck' simplifies this complex sarcastic construction into a more straightforward statement of disbelief and warning, losing the 'only if' nuance.

The French 'si vous voulez qu'on vole toûjours si mal icy' (if you insist/wish that we will always fly so badly here) has a teasing tone. The English 'tho' we cannot learn the Art here' softens this by presenting poor flying as an inability rather than her insistence, simplifying the subtle argumentative jab.

The French 'reprit-elle presque en colere' (she replied, almost in anger) provides insight into the Marquise's emotional state. The English translation 'said she' omits 'presque en colere,' simplifying by removing this character-specific emotional detail.

The French text specifies 'six mille ans' (six thousand years) and includes the philosopher's reaction 'répliquay-je en éclatant de rire' (I replied, bursting out laughing). The English translation simplifies by using the less precise 'some thousands of years' and omitting the vivid description of the philosopher's laughter, reducing factual specificity and expressive detail.

The French 'savent peut-être déjà faire' (perhaps already know how to make) includes 'peut-être' (perhaps), indicating speculation. The English 'have already made' omits 'perhaps,' presenting the idea as a more definite assertion, simplifying by removing speculative nuance.

The French 'Si vous me fâchez... je sais bien ce que j'ajoûteray encore pour le fortifier' (If you anger me... I know well what I'll add to strengthen it) is a playful threat. The English replaces this with a more formal 'I am going to demonstrate... you reproach me very unjustly:', simplifying by removing the personal, teasing tone and substituting a standard discourse marker.

The French 'à cause de l'excés ou de la chaleur, ou du froideur' (because of the excess either of heat, or of coldness) has a more analytical disjunctive structure. The English 'by reason of their excessive Heat and Cold' uses a more common adjectival phrase, a minor syntactic simplification.

The French idiomatic phrase 'il ne laissa pas de se trouver des hommes' (men were nonetheless found) is simplified to the direct existential statement 'there were Men found,' losing the nuance of something occurring despite expectations.

The French gives two reasons for disbelief: 'car on n'en avoit jamais oüy parler' (for one had never heard them spoken of) and the rhetorical question about orientation. The English omits the first reason, simplifying the argument by presenting only a rephrased version of the second.

The French 'Nouvelle reformation à la Carte, nouvelle moitié de la Terre.' is a very concise, epigrammatic statement. The English 'here's now another half of the World starts up, and a new Reformation of the Map;' expands this into more conventional prose, reducing the original's stylistic punch and density.

The translation omits the direct address 'Vous m'entendez bien, Madame' and simplifies the explicit reference 'ces Antipodes là qu'on a trouvez contre toute esperance' to the general pronoun 'this,' reducing conversational interactivity and specificity.

The French 'Le Monde achevera peut-être de se déveloper pour nous' (The world will perhaps finish unfolding for us) includes 'peut-être' (perhaps). The English 'the World will unfold it self more to us hereafter;' omits 'perhaps,' making the statement more definitive and simplifying its modality.

The translation omits the introductory clause 'Nous n'en sommes pas encore là' (We are not there yet) and the qualifying adverb 'apparemment' (apparently), making the statement more direct and assertive but simplifying its nuanced framing.

The French 'il nous sera permis de connaître' (it will be permitted to us to know) suggests future knowledge as an allowance. The English 'we shall never know that of our Neighbours [until X]' simplifies this by shifting the modality from permission to inability contingent on a condition, losing the nuance of 'permission.'

The translation omits 'en me regardant attentivement' (looking at me attentively) and softens the forceful French 'qu'il n'est pas possible que vous ne croyiez tout de bon' (it's impossible you don't believe = you must believe) to the more tentative 'that I begin to think, you are in earnest,' simplifying the intensity of her conviction and removing a descriptive detail.

The French 'mais non pas assez bien pour la persuader' (but not well enough to persuade) implies a degree of insufficiency. The English 'but never perswade him;' simplifies this by making the impossibility of persuasion absolute ('never'), removing the nuance of degree.

The French 'même sans avoir besoin de paraître avec toutes ses preuves' (even without needing to appear with all its proofs) includes 'paraître' (to appear), adding a nuance about presentation. The English 'it hath no need of all its proofs' simplifies by removing this focus on appearance.

The French 'qu'il semble qu'on ne fasse que se souvenir d'elle' (that it seems one only remembers it) conveys a specific cognitive act ('remembering') and modality ('it seems'). The English 'we do nothing but think of it' simplifies by using a more general verb ('think of it') and removing 'it seems,' making the assertion more direct.

The French 'm'incommodoit, & me faisoit mal' (inconvenienced/bothered me, and hurt me/caused me pain) uses two distinct verbs. The English 'disturb'd me' simplifies by using a single, more general verb, reducing the specificity of her discomfort.

chunks.aiHtml: P029: The Third Evening.
explanations: The English translation simplifies the original French heading by omitting the descriptive subtitle 'Particularités du monde de la Lune.' (Particularities of the world of the Moon). This omission significantly reduces the length and informational density of the heading. While this makes the heading more concise, it also renders it less specific about the content of the section, which is a clear instance of simplification by reducing text density.

chunks.sourceHtml: P039: La Marquise voulut megager pendant le jour à poursuivre nos Entretiens, mais je luy representay que nous ne devions confier nos chimeres qu'à la Lune & aux Etoiles, puis qu'aussi-bien elles en étoient l'objet. Nous ne manquâmes pas à aller le soir dans le Parc, qui devenoit un lieu consacré à nos Conversations savantes.
chunks.manualHtml: P030: THE Countess was so intent upon her Notions, that she would fain have engag'd me next day, to go on where I left off; but I told her, since the Moon and Stars were become the Subject of our Discourse, we would trust our Chymaeras with no body else: At Night we went again into the Park, which was now dedicated to our Learned Conversation.
chunks.aiHtml: P030: THE Countess was so intent upon her Notions, that she would fain have engag'd me next day, to go on where I left off; but I told her, since the Moon and Stars were become the Subject of our Discourse, we would trust our Chymaeras with no body else: At Night we went again into the Park, which was now dedicated to our Learned Conversation.
explanations: The French "poursuivre nos Entretiens" (to pursue/continue our conversations/discussions) is a relatively formal expression. The English translation "to go on where I left off" uses more common vocabulary ("go on" instead of "pursue/continue") and a more conversational, idiomatic phrasing, simplifying the expression and enhancing readability.

The French verb "representay" (from "représenter," meaning to point out, to set forth, or to explain) is more formal and lexically complex than the simple "I told her." The translation uses a more common and direct verb, reducing formality and lexical complexity, thus enhancing readability.

The French causal conjunction "puis qu'aussi-bien" ("since, moreover," or "seeing that also") is more elaborate than the simple English "since." The original phrase "elles en étoient l'objet" (they were the subject of them) is also more abstract as it relies on anaphora. The English translation simplifies the conjunction and makes the referents ("elles," "en," "l'objet") explicit by stating "the Moon and Stars" and "Subject of our Discourse," thereby reducing referential density and making the meaning more immediately accessible.

The French uses a litotes, "ne manquâmes pas à aller" ("we did not fail to go"), which is an indirect and stylistically refined way of affirming an action. The English translation simplifies this by using a direct affirmative statement, "we went again," which removes the rhetorical device and simplifies the sentence structure for easier comprehension.

chunks.sourceHtml:
P040: J'ai bien des nouvelles à vous apprendre, luy dis-je, la Lune que je vous disois hier qui selon toutes les apparences êtoit habitée, pourroit bien ne l'être point; j'ay pensé à une chose qui met ses Habitants en peril. Je ne souffriray point cela, répondit-elle. Hier vous m'aviez preparée à voir ces Gens là venir icy au premier jour, & aujourd'hui ils ne seroient seulement pas au monde? Vous ne vous joüerez point ainsi de moy, vous m'avez fait croire les Habitans de la Lune; j'ay surmonté la peine que j'y avois, je les croiray. Vous allez bien vîte, repris-je, il faut ne donner que la moitié de son esprit aux choses de cette espèce que l'on croit, & en réserver une autre moitié libre, où le contraire puisse être admis, s'il en est besoin. Je ne me paie point de Sentences, répliqua-t-elle, allons au fait. Ne faut-il pas raisonner de la Lune comme de Saint-Denis? Non, répondis-je, la Lune ne ressemble pas autant à la Terre que Saint-Denis ressemble à Paris. Le soleil éleve de la Terre & des Eaux, des exhalosons & des vapeurs qui, montant en l'air jusqu'à quelque hauteur, s'y assemblent, & forment les nüages. Ces nüages suspendus voltigent irrégulierement autour de nôtre Globe, & ombragent tantôt un Païs, tantôt un autre. Qui verroit la Terre de loin, remarqueroit souvent quelques changements sur sa surface, parce qu'un grand Païs couvert par des nüages seroit un endroit obscur, & deviendrait plus lumineux dès qu'il serait découvert. On verroit des taches qui changeroient de place, ou s'assembleroient diversement, ou disparoîtroient tout à fait. On verroit donc aussi ces mêmes changements sur la face de la Lune, si elle avoit des nüages autour d'elle; mais tout au contraire, toutes ses taches sont fixes, ses endroits lumineux le sont toûjours, & voilà le malheur. A ce compte-là, le Soleil n'élève point de vapeurs, ny d'exhalaisons de dessus la Lune. C'est donc un Corps infiniment plus dur & plus solide que notre Terre, dont les parties les plus subtiles se dégagent aisément d'avec les autres, & montent en haut dés qu'elles sont mises en mouvement par la chaleur. Il faut que ce soit quelque amas de Rochers & de Marbres, où il ne se fait point d'évaporations; d'ailleurs, elles se font si naturellement & si necessairement où il y a des Eaux, qu'il ne doit point y avoir d'eaux ou il ne s'en fait point. Qui sont donc les Habitans de ces Rochers qui ne peuvent rien produire, & de ce Païs qui n'a point d'eaux? Et quoi, s'écria-t-elle, il ne vous souvient plus que vous m'avez assurée qu'il y avoit dans la Lune des Mers que l'on distinguoit d'icy? Ce n'est qu'une conjecture, répondis-je, j'en suis bien fâché; ces endroits obscurs qu'on prend pour des Mers, ne sont peut-être que de grandes cavitez. De la distance où nous sommes, il est permis de ne pas deviner tout à fait juste. Mais, dit-elle, cela suffira-t-il pour nous faire abandonner les Habitans de la Lune? Non pas tout à fait, Madame, répondis-je, nous ne nous déterminerons ni pour eux, ny contre eux. Je vous avouë ma faiblesse, répliqua-t-elle, je ne suis point capable d'une si parfaite indétermination, j'ay besoin de croire. Fixez-moy promptement à une opinion sur les Habitans de la Lune; conservons les, ou aneantissons les pour jamais & qu'il n'en soit plus parlé; mais conservons les plutôt, s'il se peut, j'ay pris pour eux une inclination que j'aurois de la peine à perdre. Je ne laisseray donc pas la Lune deserte, repris-je, repeuplons là pour vous faire plaisir. A la vérité, puisque l'apparence des taches de la Lune ne change point, on ne peut pas croire qu'elle ait des nüages autour d'elle, qui ombragent tantôt une partie, tantôt une autre; mais ce n'est pas à dire qu'elle ne pousse point hors d'elle de vapeurs ny d'exhalaisons. Nos nüages que nous voïons portez en l'air ne sont que des exhalaisons & des vapeurs, qui au sortir de la Terre êtaient separées en trop petites parties pour pouvoir être veuës, & qui ont rencontré un peu plus haut une froideur qui les a resserrées, & renduës visibles par la reünion de leurs parties, aprés quoy ce sont de gros nüages qui flotent en l'air où ils sont des Corps étrangers, jusqu'à ce qu'ils retombet en pluyes. Mais ces mêmes vapeurs, & ces mêmes exhalaisons se tiennent quelquefois assez dispersées pour être imperceptibles, & ne se ramassent qu'en formant des rosées tres subtiles, qu'on ne voit tomber d'aucune nuée. Il se peut aussi que les vapeurs qui sortent de la Lune, (car enfin il faut qu'il en sorte, il n'est pas croyable que la Lune soit une masse dont toutes les parties soient d'une égale solidité; toutes également en repos les unes auprés des autres, toutes incapables de recevoir aucun changement par l'action du Soleil sur elles; nous ne connoissons aucun Corps de cette nature, les Marbres mêmes n'en sont pas, tout ce qui est le plus solide change & s'altere, ou par le mouvement secret & invisible qu'il a en luy-même, ou par celuy qu'il reçoit de dehors.) Il se peut donc que les vapeurs qui sortent de la Lune, ne se rassemblent point autour d'elle en nuages, & ne retomberont point sur elle en pluyes, mais seulement en rosées. Il suffit pour cela que l'air dont apparemment la Lune est environnée en son particulier, comme notre Terre l'est du sien, soit un peu different de notre Air, & les vapeurs de la Lune un peu differentes des vapeurs de la Terre, ce qui est quelque chose de plus que vraysemblable. Sur ce pied là, il faudra que la matière étant disposée dans la Lune autrement que sur la Terre, les effets soient diferens, mais il n'importe; du moment que nous avons trouvé un mouvement interieur dans les parties de la Lune, ou produit par des causes étrangeres, voilà ses Habitans qui renaissent, & nous avons le fond necessaire pour leur subsistance. Cela nous fournira des fruits, des blés, des eaux, & tout ce que nous voudrons. J'entends des fruits, des bleds, des eaux à la maniere de la Lune que je fais profession de ne pas connoître, le tout proportionné aux besoins de ses Habitans, que je ne connais pas non plus.

P041: C'est-à-dire, me dit la Marquise, que vous savez seulement que tout est bien, sans savoir comment il est; c'est beaucoup d'ignorance sur bien peu de science; mais il faut s'en consoler; je suis encore trop heureuse que vous ayez rendu à la Lune ses Habitans. Je suis même fort contente que vous luy donniez un Air qui l'enveloppe en son particulier, il me semblerait desormais que sans cela une Planete seroit trop nuë.
chunks.manualHtml: P031: Well, Madam, said I, I have great News for you; that which I told you last Night, of the Moon's being inhabited, may not be so now: There is a new Fancy got into my Head, which puts those People in great Danger. I cannot suffer it, said she; yesterday you were preparing me to receive a Visit from 'em, and now there are no such People in Nature: Once you would have me believe the Moon was inhabited; I surmounted the Difficulty I had, and will now believe it. You are a little too nimble, I reply'd; did I not advise you never to be entirely convinc'd in things of this nature, but to reserve half of your understanding free and disengag'd, that you may admit of the contrary opinion, if there be any occasion. I care not for your Sentences, said she, let us come to matter of Fact. Are we not to consider the Moon as Greenwhich? No, said I, the Moon doth not so much resemble the Earth, as Greenwich doth London: The Sun draws from the Earth and Water, Exhalations and Vapours, which mounting to a certain height in the Air, do there assemble, and form the Clouds; these uncertain Clouds are driven irregularly round the Globe, sometimes shadowing one Countrey, and sometimes another; he then who beholds the Earth from a-far off, will see frequent alterations upon its surface, because a great Country overcast with Clouds, will appear dark or light, as the Clouds stay, or pass over it; he will see the Spots on the Earth often change their Place, and appear, or disappear as the Clouds remove; but we see none of these changes wrought upon the Moon, which would certainly be the same, were there but Clouds about her; but on the contrary, all her Spots are fix'd and certain, and her light parts continue where they were at first, which truly is a great misfortune; for by this reason, the Sun draws no Exhalations or Vapours above the Moon; so that it appears she is a Body infinitely more hard, and solid than the Earth, whose subtile parts are easily separated from the rest, and mount upwards as soon as Heat puts them in Motion: But it must be a heap of Rock and Marble, where there is no Evaporation; besides, Exhalations are so natural and necessary where there is Water, that there can be no Water at all, where there is no Exhalation; and what sort of Inhabitants must those be, whose Countrey affords no Water, is all Rock, and produceth nothing? Very fine, said she, you have forgot since, you assur'd me, we might from hence distinguish Seas in the Moon; nay, You or your Friends were Godfathers to some of 'em. Pray, what is become of your Caspian Sea, and your Black Lake? All Conjecture, Madam, I reply'd, tho' for your Ladyships sake, I am very sorry for it; for those dark places we took to be Seas, may perhaps be nothing but large Cavities; 'tis hard to guess aright at so great a distance. But will this suffice then, said she, to extirpate the People in the Moon? Not altogether, I reply'd, we will neither determine for, nor against them. I must own my weakness (if it be one) said she, I cannot be so perfectly undetermin'd as you would have me to be, but must believe one way, or the other; therefore pray fix me quickly in my opinion; as to the Inhabitants of the Moon; preserve or annihilate them, as you shall think fit; and yet methinks I have a strange inclination for 'em, and would not have 'em destroy'd, if it were possible to save 'em. You know, Madam, said I, I can deny you nothing; the Moon shall be no longer a Defart, but to do you service, we will repeople her. Since to all appearance, the Spots in the Moon do not change, I cannot conceive there are any Clouds about her, that sometimes obscure one part, and sometimes another; yet this doth not hinder, but that the Moon sends forth Exhalations, and Vapours. Our Clouds which we see in the Air, are nothing but Exhalations and Vapours, which at their coming out of the Earth, were separated into such minute Particles, that they could not be discern'd; but as they ascend higher, they are condens'd by the Cold, and by the re- union of their Parts, are render'd visible; after which they become great Clouds, which fluctuate in the Air, till they return back again in Rain; however these Exhalations and Vapours do sometimes keep themselves so dispers'd, that they are imperceptible; or if they do assemble, it is in forming such subtile Dews, that they cannot be discern'd to fall from any Cloud. It may likewise happen, that the Vapours which go out of the Moon (for it is incredible that the Moon is such a Mass, that all its Parts are of an equal Solidity, all at rest one with another, and all incapable of any alteration from the efficacy of the Sun; I am sure we are yet unacquainted with such a Body: Marble it self is of another Nature, and even that which is most Solid, is subject to Change and Alteration; either from the secret and invisible motion it hath within it self, or from that which it receives from without) it may so happen then, that the Vapours which issue from the Moon, may not assemble round her in Clouds, and may not fall back again in Rain, but only in Dews. It is sufficient for this, that the Air with which the Moon is environ'd, (for it is certain that the Moon is encompassed with Air as well as the Earth) be a little different from our Air, and the Vapours of the Moon a little different from those of the Earth, which is very probable. Hereupon the matter being otherwise dispos'd in the Moon than on the Earth, the Effects must be different; tho' it is of no great consequence whether they are or no; for from the moment we have found an inward motion in the parts of the Moon, or produced by foreign Causes, here is enough for the new birth of its Inhabitants, and a sufficient and necessary fund for their Subsistence. This will furnish us with Corn, Fruit, Water, according to the custom or manner of the Moon, which I do not pretend to know; and all proportion'd to the wants and use of the Inhabitants, with whom I pretend to be as little acquainted. That is to say, reply'd the Countess, you know all is very well, without knowing how it is so, which is a great deal of Ignorance upon a very little Knowledge; however I comfort my self, that you have given the Moon her Inhabitants again, and have wrap'd her in an Air of her own, without which a Planet would seem but very naked.

It may likewise happen, that the Vapours which go out of the Moon (for it is incredible that the Moon is such a Mass, that all its Parts are of an equal Solidity, all at rest one with another, and all incapable of any alteration from the efficacy of the Sun; I am sure we are yet unacquainted with such a Body: Marble it self is of another Nature, and even that which is most Solid, is subject to Change and Alteration; either from the secret and invisible motion it hath within it self, or from that which it receives from without) it may so happen then, that the Vapours which issue from the Moon, may not assemble round her in Clouds, and may not fall back again in Rain, but only in Dews. It is sufficient for this, that the Air with which the Moon is environ'd, (for it is certain that the Moon is encompassed with Air as well as the Earth) be a little different from our Air, and the Vapours of the Moon a little different from those of the Earth, which is very probable. Hereupon the matter being otherwise dispos'd in the Moon than on the Earth, the Effects must be different; tho' it is of no great consequence whether they are or no; for from the moment we have found an inward motion in the parts of the Moon, or produced by foreign Causes, here is enough for the new birth of its Inhabitants, and a sufficient and necessary fund for their Subsistence. This will furnish us with Corn, Fruit, Water, according to the custom or manner of the Moon, which I do not pretend to know; and all proportion'd to the wants and use of the Inhabitants, with whom I pretend to be as little acquainted. That is to say, reply'd the Countess, you know all is very well, without knowing how it is so, which is a great deal of Ignorance upon a very little Knowledge; however I comfort my self, that you have given the Moon her Inhabitants again, and have wrap'd her in an Air of her own, without which a Planet would seem but very naked.
explanations: The French phrase "selon toutes les apparences" (according to all appearances), which qualifies the likelihood of the Moon being inhabited, is omitted in the English translation. This simplifies the statement by removing a layer of nuance regarding the certainty of the claim.

The translator omitted the Marquise's indignant phrase "Vous ne vous joüerez point ainsi de moy" (You will not play/trifle with me like this). This reduces the text's length and simplifies the Marquise's emotional reaction by removing a direct expression of her frustration.

The original French "il faut ne donner que la moitié de son esprit... que l'on croit" (one must only give half of one's mind... that one believes) uses a metaphorical and impersonal construction. The English translation "never to be entirely convinc'd" simplifies this into a more direct and common expression. Additionally, the impersonal "il faut" (one must) is changed to a personal reminder "did I not advise you," simplifying the philosophical tone to direct advice.

The French phrase "s'assembleroient diversement" (would assemble themselves variously/in different ways), describing the changing appearance of spots (clouds), is simplified in the English translation to just "appear". This omits the specific detail of the spots forming or gathering in various configurations, reducing the descriptive richness and density of the original.

The French interjection "Et quoi!" (What!), expressing strong surprise or indignation, is translated as "Very fine". This English phrase, typically used sarcastically in such contexts, simplifies the direct emotional outburst of the original into a more conventional and stylistically less sharp expression of disapproval.

The original French "il est permis de ne pas deviner tout à fait juste" (it is permissible / one is allowed not to guess entirely correctly) is a somewhat formal and abstract turn of phrase. The English translation "'tis hard to guess aright" simplifies this into a more direct, colloquial, and concrete statement, enhancing immediate readability.

The translator omits the French phrase "& qu'il n'en soit plus parlé" (and let nothing more be said of them), which was part of the Marquise's command. This omission reduces the length and simplifies the original imperative. Furthermore, the nuanced phrase "j'ay pris pour eux une inclination que j'aurois de la peine à perdre" (I have taken for them an inclination that I would have difficulty losing) is rephrased as "methinks I have a strange inclination for 'em, and would not have 'em destroy'd, if it were possible to save 'em," which simplifies the psychological detail by focusing on a consequence rather than the specific nature of the enduring feeling.

The French text includes the clause "où ils sont des Corps étrangers" (where they are foreign bodies), referring to clouds in the air. The English translation omits this clause. This simplification removes a specific conceptual detail about the nature of clouds as distinct entities within the atmosphere, reducing the density of the scientific explanation.

The French phrase "ce qui est quelque chose de plus que vraysemblable" (which is something more than probable/likely) offers a nuanced and slightly understated expression of high probability. The English translation "which is very probable" simplifies this to a more direct and common adverbial intensifier, losing the subtle graduation of likelihood present in the original.

The French sentence begins with "J'entends" (I mean / I understand this as), which explicitly marks the subsequent statement as a clarification or specific interpretation by the speaker. The English translation omits this introductory phrase, integrating the clarification directly into the preceding thought ("This will furnish us..."). This omission simplifies the rhetorical structure by removing the explicit marker of self-clarification.

The French "que vous savez seulement que tout est bien" (that you only know that all is well) includes the restrictive adverb "seulement" (only). The English translation "you know all is very well" omits this qualifier. This simplification removes an explicit limitation on the philosopher's knowledge as perceived by the Marquise.

The French clause "Je suis même fort contente que vous luy donniez un Air qui l'enveloppe en son particulier" (I am even very content that you give it an Air that envelops it in its own particular way) is significantly condensed in the English translation. The phrase "and have wrap'd her in an Air of her own" simplifies the original by converting it into a participial phrase linked to the previous statement. This omits the explicit declaration of contentment ("Je suis même fort contente") and renders the complex description "un Air qui l'enveloppe en son particulier" with the simpler "an Air of her own," thus reducing both sentence complexity and explicitly stated emotional content.

chunks.sourceHtml: P042: Ces deux Airs diferens, repris-je, contribuent à empêcher la communication des deux Planetes. S'il ne tenoit qu'à voler; que savons-nous, comme je vous disois hier, si on ne volera pas fort bien quelque jour? J'avoüe pourtant qu'il n'y a pas beaucoup d'apparence. Le grand éloignement de la Lune à la Terre serait encore une difficulté à surmonter, qui est assurement considerable, mais quand même elle ne s'y rencontreroit pas, quand même les deux Planetes seroient proches, il ne seroit pas possible de passer de l'Air de l'une dans l'air de l'autre. L'eau est l'air des Poissons, ils ne passent jamais dans l'Air des Oiseaux dans l'air des Poissons; ce n'est pas la distance qui les en empêche, c'est que chacun a pour prison l'air qu'il respire. Nous trouvons que le nôtre est mêlé de vapeurs plus épaisses & plus grossières que celuy de la Lune. A ce compte, un Habitan de la Lune qui seroit arrivé aux confins de notre Monde, se noyeroit dés qu'il entreroit dans notre Air, & nous le verrions tomber mort sur la Terre.
chunks.manualHtml: P032: 'Tis these two different Airs, said I, that hinder the Communication of the two Planets; if it was only flying, as I told you yesterday, who knows but we may improve it to perfection, tho' I confess there is but little hopes of it; the great distance between the Moon and the Earth is a difficulty not easily to be surmounted, yet were the distance but inconsiderable, and the two Planets almost contiguous, it would be still impossible to pass from the Air of the one, into the Air of the other: The Water is the Air of Fishes, they never pass into the Air of the Birds, nor the Birds into the Air of the Fish; and yet 'tis not the distance that hinders them, but both are emprison'd by the Air they breath in; we find our Air consists of thicker and grosser Vapours than the Air of the Moon. So that one of her Inhabitants arriving at the Confines of our World, as soon as he enters our Air will inevitably drown himself, and we shall see him fall dead on the Earth.

explanations: The French phrase "qu'il n'y a pas beaucoup d'apparence" (meaning there isn't much likelihood or prospect) is rendered as "there is but little hopes of it." The English uses more common and arguably less abstract vocabulary ("hopes" instead of a direct equivalent of "apparence" in this sense), simplifying for readability.

The French uses a conditional "serait" (would be) and a relative clause "qui est assurement considerable" (which is certainly considerable). The translation simplifies this by using the present tense "is" for greater directness and by condensing the description into the phrase "not easily to be surmounted." This integrates the meaning of overcoming a considerable difficulty into a more compact adjectival phrase, reducing clausal complexity.

The original French phrase "ils ne passent jamais dans l'Air des Oiseaux dans l'air des Poissons" is potentially awkward or elliptical if "ils" refers only to fish. The English translation clarifies this by explicitly structuring the comparison with the parallel clause "nor the Birds into the Air of the Fish," which simplifies the syntax for the reader and ensures the intended symmetrical restriction is clear.

The French construction "chacun a pour prison l'air" (literally, 'each one has for prison the air') is somewhat formal. The English translation "both are emprison'd by the Air" simplifies this by using a more direct participial adjective construction ("emprison'd") and by specifying "both" (referring to fish and birds), making the statement more concrete and employing a more common English phrasing.

The French idiomatic phrase "A ce compte," (meaning 'on this account,' 'by this reckoning,' or 'consequently') is translated to the simpler and more common English connective "So that," streamlining the introduction of the conclusion.

chunks.sourceHtml: P043: Oh, que j'aurois d'envie, s'écria la Marquise, qu'il arrivât quelque grand naufrage qui répandît icy bon nombre de ces Gens- là, dont nous irions considérer à notre aise les figures extraordinaires! Mais répliquay-je, s'ils étoient assez habiles pour naviger sur la surface exterieure de notre Air, & que de là par la curiosité de nous voir, ils nous pêchassent comme des Poissons, cela vous plairoit-il? Pourquoy non, répondit-elle en riant? Pour moy, je me mettrois de mon propre mouvement dans leurs Filets, seulement pour avoir le plaisir de voir ceux qui m'auroient pêchée.
chunks.manualHtml: P033: I should rejoyce at a Wreck, said the Countess, as much as my Neighbours on the Coast of Sussex; how pleasant would it be to see 'em lie scatter'd on the ground, where we might consider at our ease, their extraordinary Figures? But what, said I, if they could swim on the outward surface of our Air, and be as curious to see us, as you are to see them; should they Angle or cast a Net for us, as for so many Fish, would that please you? why not? said the Countess; For my part I would go into their Nets of mine own accord, were it but for the pleasure to see such strange Fishermen.

explanations: The French uses a complex conditional subjunctive construction `j'aurois d'envie... qu'il arrivât` (I would have a desire... that it might happen) to express a strong wish. The English translation simplifies this to the more direct modal expression "I should rejoyce at a Wreck," reducing grammatical complexity and making the desire more straightforward.

The French clause `qui répandît icy bon nombre de ces Gens-là` (that would scatter here a good number of these People) is rephrased. The term `bon nombre de ces Gens-là` (a good number of these People) is heavily simplified to the colloquial "'em" (them). The verb `répondît` (would scatter/spread) is rendered with the more vivid and common phrase "lie scatter'd," and "icy" (here) becomes the more concrete "on the ground." This reduces lexical density, formality, and simplifies vocabulary.

The French phrase `assez habiles pour naviger` (skilled enough to navigate) within the conditional clause is simplified to "could swim." "Swim" is a more common and less formal verb than "navigate." The construction "could swim" is also more direct and concise than "were skilled enough to navigate," reducing lexical complexity and length.

The French single subordinate clause, which compactly links location (`de là`), motivation (`par la curiosité de nous voir`), and action (`ils nous pêchassent`), is restructured into two English clauses connected by a semicolon. This unpacking simplifies the dense original structure. The French subjunctive `pêchassent` (they might fish) is replaced by the modal construction "should they Angle or cast a Net," simplifying the grammatical mood for an English audience and making the hypothetical action easier to parse.

The translator omitted the participial phrase `en riant` (laughing), which describes the manner of the Marquise's (Countess's) reply. This omission simplifies the sentence by removing a descriptive detail, reducing the density of the text and its stylistic nuance.

The French reflexive construction `je me mettrois` (I would put myself) is simplified to "I would go." "Go" is a more common and direct verb in this context than the more elaborate "put myself" (or "enter"), streamlining the description of the action.

The French relative clause `ceux qui m'auroient pêchée` (those who would have fished me), which uses a conditional perfect tense to identify specific hypothetical individuals, is simplified to the descriptive noun phrase "such strange Fishermen." This avoids the complex verbal construction and relative clause, opting for a shorter, more direct, and lexically simpler phrase, though it also alters the nuance by adding "strange" and generalizing the agents.

chunks.sourceHtml: P044: Songez, répliquai-je, que vous n'arriveriez que bien malade au haut de notre Air, il n'est pas respirable pour nous dans toute son étenduê, il s'en faut bien, il ne l'est déjà presque plus au haut de certaines Montagnes, & je m'étonne bien que ceux qui ont la folie de croire que des Genies corporels habitent l'air le plus pur, ne disent aussi que ce qui fait que ces Genies ne nous rendent que des visites & tres-rares & très-courtes, c'est qu'il y en a peu d'entre eux qui sachent plonger, & que ceux-là même ne peuvent faire jusqu'au fond de cet air épais, où nous sommes, que des plongeons de très peu de durée. Voilà donc bien des barrieres naturelles qui nous défendent la sortie de notre Monde, & l'entrée de celuy de la Lune. Tâchons du moins pour notre consolation à deviner ce que nous pourrons de ce Monde-là. Je croy, par exemple, qu'il faut qu'on y voye le Ciel, le Soleil, & les Astres d'une autre couleur que nous ne les voyons. Tous ces objets ne nous paroissent qu'au travers d'une espèce de Lunette naturelle qui nous les change. Cette Lunette, c'est notre Air, mêlé comme il est de vapeurs & d'exhalaisons, & qui ne s'étend pas bien haut. Quelques Modernes pretendent que de luy-même il est bleu aussi bien que l'eau de la Mer, & que cette couleur ne paroît dans l'un & dans l'autre qu'à une grande profondeur. Le Ciel, disent-ils, où sont attachées les Etoiles Fixes, n'a de luy-même aucune lumière, & par conséquent il devroit paroître noir; mais on le voit au travers de l'Air, qui est bleu, & il paraît bleu. Si cela est, les rayons du Soleil & des Etoiles ne peuvent passer au travers de l'Air sans se teindre un peu de sa couleur, & prendre autant de celle qui leur est naturelle. Mais quand même l'Air ne seroit pas coloré de lui-même, il est certain qu'au travers d'un gros brouillard, la lumiere d'un flambeau qu'on voit un peu de loin paroît toute rougeâtre, quoy que ce ne soit pas sa vraye couleur, & notre Air n'est non plus qu'un gros broüillard, qui nous doit alterer la vraye couleur & du Ciel & du Soleil & des Etoiles. Il n'appartiendroit qu'à la matière céleste de nous apporter la lumiere & les couleurs dans toute leur pureté, & telles qu'elles sont. Ainsi, puis que l'Air de la Lune est d'une autre nature que notre Air, ou il est teint en luy-même d'une autre couleur, ou du moins c'est un autre broüillard qui cause une autre alteration aux couleurs des Corps celestes. Enfin, à l'égard des Gens de la Lune, cette Lunette au travers de laquelle on voit tout, est changée.
chunks.manualHtml: P034: You would be very Sick, said I, when you were drawn to the top of our Air, for it is not respirable in all its extent, as may be seen on the tops of some very high Mountains; and I admire that they who have the folly to believe that our Faries, whom they alow to be Corporeal, and to inhabit the most pure and refin'd Air, do not tell us that the reason why they give us such short and seldom visits, is that there are very few among them that can dive, and those that can, if it be possible to get through the thick Air where we are, cannot stay half so long in it, as one of the worst of Sir Harry Blount's Sponge- gatherers. Here then are natural Barricades, which defend the passage out of our World, as well as the Entry into that of the Moon; so that since we can only guess at that World, let us fancy all we can of it. For Example, I will suppose that we may see there the Firmament, the Sun, and the Stars, of another colour than what they are here; all these apear to us through a kind of Natural Spectacles, which change and alter the Objects. These Spectacles are our Air, mix'd as it is with Vapours and Exhalations, and which doth not extend it self very high. Some of our Modern Philosophers pretend, of it self it is blue, as well as the Water of the Sea, and that this colour neither appears in the one nor in the other, but at a great depth; the Firmament, say they, where the fix'd Stars are fastned, hath no peculiar light of its own, and by consequence must appear black, but we see it through the Air which is blue, and therefore to us it appears blue; which if so, the Beams of the Sun and Stars cannot pass through the Air without being ting'd a little with its colour, and losing as much of their own; yet were the Air of no colour, it is very certain, that through a great Mist the light of a Flambeau at some distance appears reddish, though it be not its true natural colour. Our Air is nothing but a great Mist, which changeth the true colour of the Sky, of the Sun, and of the Stars; it belongs only to the Celestial Matter to bring us the Light and Colours as they really are in all the purity; so that since the Air of the Moon is of another nature than our Air, or is stain'd of another colour, or at least is another kind of Mist, which causeth other alterations to the Colours of the Celestial Bodies; in short, as to the People of the Moon, their Spectacles through which they see every thing are chang'd.

explanations: The French intensifier "il s'en faut bien," (far from it), used to emphasize the lack of respirability of the air, is omitted in the translation. This simplification reduces the density of the text by removing an idiomatic expression, making the statement more direct.

The French term "Genies corporels" (corporeal spirits or genii) is rendered as "our Faries." This substitution simplifies the original by using a more common and culturally familiar term ("Faries") for the English audience of the time, making the concept more immediately accessible than the more philosophical "Genies."

The clause "pour notre consolation" (for our consolation) is omitted in the English translation. This simplifies the sentence by removing an explicit statement of motivation, making the core exhortation more direct and concise.

The French "Je croy... qu'il faut qu'on y voye..." (I believe... that one must see there...), which employs an impersonal modal ("il faut que") and implies a subjunctive, is simplified to "I will suppose that we may see...". This change makes the sentence structure less complex by using a more direct personal assertion ("I will suppose") and a simpler modal auxiliary ("may see"), enhancing readability.

The French impersonal pronoun in "on le voit" (one sees it) is translated to the personal "we see it," and the simple "il paraît bleu" (it appears blue) is expanded with "therefore to us" in "and therefore to us it appears blue;". This shift from impersonal to personal constructions simplifies the formality of the original, making the text more direct and engaging for the reader.

The French phrase "& prendre autant de celle qui leur est naturelle," which literally means "and take as much of that which is natural to them" and contextually implies a loss of their own color, is translated more directly as "and losing as much of their own [natural color];". This simplification clarifies a potentially ambiguous or less direct expression by making the meaning of loss explicit.

The French "qui nous doit alterer la vraye couleur" (which must alter for us the true colour) includes the pronoun "nous" (us/for us), directly linking the effect to the observers. The English translation "which changeth the true colour" omits this explicit reference to "us." This simplification makes the statement more general by removing the specific observer-oriented perspective, thereby reducing a layer of textual detail.

The French conditional "Il n'appartiendroit qu'à..." (It would only belong to...) is translated into the present indicative "it belongs only to...". This change simplifies the original by replacing a more formal and hypothetical conditional mood with a direct indicative statement, making the assertion less nuanced and more straightforward.

The French impersonal construction "on voit tout" (one sees everything) within the larger clause is rendered as "they see every thing." This simplification replaces an abstract impersonal agent with a specific personal pronoun ("they," referring to the Moon's inhabitants), making the sentence more direct and less formal.

chunks.sourceHtml:
P045: Cela me fait préférer notre sejour à celuy de la Lune, dit la Marquise, je ne saurois croire que l'assortiment des couleurs celestes y soit aussi beau qu'il l'est icy. Mettons, si vous voulez, un Ciel rouge, & des Etoiles vertes, l'effet n'est pas si agreable que des Etoiles couleur d'or sur du bleu. On diroit à vous entendre,, repris-je, que vous assortiriez un habit, ou un meuble; mais, croyez-moy, la Nature a bien de l'esprit; laissez-luy le soin d'inventer un assortiment de couleurs pour la Lune, & je vous garantis qu'il sera bien entendu. Elle n'aura pas manqué de varier le Spectacle de l'Univers à chaque point de veüe diferent, & de le varier d'une manière toûjours agreable.

P046: Je reconnois son adresse, interrompit la Marquise, elle s'est épargné la peine de changer les objets pour chaque point de veûe, elle n'a changé que les Lunettes, & elle a l'honneur de cette grande diversité, sans en avoir fait la dépense. Avec un air bleu, elle nous donne un Ciel bleu, & peut-être avec un Air rouge, elle donne un Ciel rouge aux Habitans de la Lune, c'est pourtant toûjours le même Ciel. Il me paroît qu'elle nous a mis dans l'imagination certaines Lunettes, au travers desquelles on voit tout, & qui changent fort les objets à l'égard de chaque homme. Alexandre voyoit la Terre comme une belle place bien propre à y établir un grand Empire. Celadon ne la voyoit que comme le sejour d'Astrée. Un Philosophe la voit comme une grosse Planète qui va par les Cieux, toute couverte de fous. Je ne croy pas que le Spectacle change plus de la Terre à la Lune, qu'il fait icy d'imagination à imagination.
chunks.manualHtml: P035: If it be so, said the Countess, I prefer my abode before that of the Moon; for I cannot believe the Celestial Colours are so well suited as they are here; for if you will let us put green Stars on a red Sky, they cannot be so agreable as Stars of Gold on an Azure Firmament. To hear you, said I, one would think you was chusing a Petticoat, or a suit of Knots; but believe me, Nature hath as good a Fancy as Mrs. Harrison; leave it to her to chuse Colours for the Moon, and I'll engage they shall be well sorted; she will not fail to vary the Prospect of the Universe, at every different point of Sight, and always the Alteration shall be very agreable. I know very well, said the Countess, her Skill in this Point; she is not at the charge of changing the Objects, but only the Spectacles, and hath the credit of this great variety, without being at any expence; with a blue Air, she gives us a blue Firmament; and perhaps with a red Air, she gives to the Inhabitants of the Moon a red Firmament; and yet still it is but the same Firmament; nay, I am of opinion, she hath plac'd a sort of Spectacles in our Imagination, through which we see all things, and which to every particular Man change the Objects. Alexander look'd on the Earth as a fit place to establish a great Empire, it seem'd to Celadon a proper residence for Astraea, and it appear'd to a Philosopher, a great Planet in the Heavens, covered with Fools: I do not believe the Sights vary more between the Earth and the Moon, than they do between one Man's Fancy and anothers.

To hear you, said I, one would think you was chusing a Petticoat, or a suit of Knots; but believe me, Nature hath as good a Fancy as Mrs. Harrison; leave it to her to chuse Colours for the Moon, and I'll engage they shall be well sorted; she will not fail to vary the Prospect of the Universe, at every different point of Sight, and always the Alteration shall be very agreable. I know very well, said the Countess, her Skill in this Point; she is not at the charge of changing the Objects, but only the Spectacles, and hath the credit of this great variety, without being at any expence; with a blue Air, she gives us a blue Firmament; and perhaps with a red Air, she gives to the Inhabitants of the Moon a red Firmament; and yet still it is but the same Firmament; nay, I am of opinion, she hath plac'd a sort of Spectacles in our Imagination, through which we see all things, and which to every particular Man change the Objects. Alexander look'd on the Earth as a fit place to establish a great Empire, it seem'd to Celadon a proper residence for Astraea, and it appear'd to a Philosopher, a great Planet in the Heavens, covered with Fools: I do not believe the Sights vary more between the Earth and the Moon, than they do between one Man's Fancy and anothers.
explanations: The French "je ne saurois croire" (a nuanced conditional form suggesting 'I couldn't bring myself to believe' or 'I wouldn't know how to believe') is simplified to the more direct and common "I cannot believe." This reduces the stylistic nuance and uses more standard vocabulary for the assertion.

The French "inventer un assortiment de couleurs" (to invent an assortment of colours) is more elaborate than the English "to chuse Colours." "Chuse" represents a simpler action and uses more common vocabulary than the multi-word concept of "inventing an assortment."

The French "bien entendu" can mean well-conceived, well-arranged, or tasteful, carrying a degree of intellectual or aesthetic judgment. The English "well sorted" is simpler and more concrete vocabulary, focusing on a basic aspect of arrangement and thereby reducing the original's semantic richness.

The abstract French phrase "la Nature a bien de l'esprit" (Nature has much wit/spirit/intelligence) is simplified by replacing it with a concrete, contemporary (for the translator's time) comparison: "Nature hath as good a Fancy as Mrs. Harrison." This enhances accessibility by exchanging a philosophical abstraction for a more colloquial and relatable analogy, reducing its stylistic complexity.

The concise French noun "adresse" (skill, cleverness, adroitness) is translated into the more periphrastic and explicit phrase "her Skill in this Point." This breaks down a single nuanced term into simpler, more direct components, making its meaning more immediately accessible but less condensed.

The French construction "sans en avoir fait la dépense" (literally 'without having made the expenditure for it'), which uses the referential pronoun "en," is rendered as the more direct prepositional phrase "without being at any expence." This simplifies the syntax by avoiding the indirect object pronoun common in French.

The adverb "fort" (greatly/very much), which modifies "changent" (change) in the French phrase "changent fort les objets" (greatly change the objects), is omitted in the English translation. This reduces the intensity conveyed in the original and simplifies the phrase by removing a modifier, thus lessening textual density.

The French phrase "une belle place bien propre à y établir" (a beautiful place very suitable for establishing there) is simplified in the English translation. The adjective "belle" (beautiful) is omitted, and the descriptive phrase "bien propre à" (very suitable/apt for) is reduced to the simpler and more common term "fit." This involves using more common vocabulary and reducing descriptive detail.

The French "qui va par les Cieux" (that goes/travels through the Heavens) clearly indicates motion. The English translation "in the Heavens" is static, omitting the element of movement. Additionally, the French "toute couverte de fous" (all/entirely covered with fools) is rendered as "covered with Fools," omitting the intensifier "toute" (all/entirely). Both changes simplify the original by reducing descriptive detail and textual density.

chunks.sourceHtml: P047: Le changement de spectacle est plus surprenant dans nos imaginations, répliquay-je, car ce ne sont que les mêmes objets qu'on voit si diferemment; du moins dans la Lune on peut voir d'autres objets, ou ne pas voir quelques-uns de ceux qu'on voit icy. Peut-être ne connaissent-ils point en ce Pays-là l'Aurore, ny les Crepuscules, avant che le Soleil se leve, ou après qu'il est couché. L 'Air qui nous environne, & qui est élevé au-dessus de nous, reçoit des rayons qui ne pourroient pas tomber sur la Terre; & parce qu'il est fort grossier, il en arrête une partie, & nous les renvoye, quoy qu'ils ne nous fussent pas naturellement destinés. Ainsi l'Aurore & les Crépuscules sont une grace que la Nature nous fait; c'est une lumiere que regulièrement nous ne devrions point avoir, & qu'elle nous donne par dessus ce qui nous est dû. Mais dans la Lune, où apparemment l'Air est plus pur, il pourroit bien n'être pas si propre à renvoyer en en bas les rayons qu'il reçoit du Soleil avant qu'il se leve, ou aprés qu'il est couché. Vous n'avez donc cette lumiere de faveur, qui en se fortifiant peu à peu, vous prepare agreablement à l'arrivée du Soleil, ou qui en s'affoiblissant comme de nuance en nuance, vous accoûtume à sa perte. Vous êtes dans des tenebres profondes, & tout d'un coup il semble qu'on tire un rideau, voilà vos yeux frapez de tout l'éclat qui est dans le Soleil; vous êtes dans une lumière vive & éclatante, & tout d'un coup vous voilà tombés dans des tenebres profondes. Le jour & la nuit ne sont point liez par un milieu qui tienne de l'un & de l'autre. L'Arc-en-ciel est encore une chose qui manque aux Gens de la Lune, car si l'Aurore est un effet de la grossiereté de l'air & des vapeurs, l'Arc-en-ciel se forme dans les nuages d'ou tombent les pluyes, & nous devons les plus belles choses du monde à celles qui le sont le moins. Puis qu'il n'y a autour de la Lune ny vapeurs assez grossières, ny nuages pluvieux, adieu l'Arc-en-ciel avec l'Aurore, & à quoy ressembleront les Belles de ce Pays-là? Quelle source de comparaisons perduë!
chunks.manualHtml: P036: This change in our Imaginations, said I, is very surprizing; for they are still the same Objects, tho' they appear different; when in the Moon, we may see other Objects we do not see here, or at least, not see all there we do see here; perhaps in that Country they know nothing of the Dawn and the Twilight, before the Sun riseth, and after the Sun sets; the Air which encompasseth, and is elevated above us, receives the Rays, so that they cannot strike on the Earth; and being gross, stops some of them, and sends 'em to us, tho' indeed they were never naturally design'd us; so that the Day-break and the Twilight are a favour which Nature bestows on us; they are a Light which regularly we should not have, and which she gives us over and above our due; but in the Moon, where apparently the Air is more pure, and therefore not so proper to send down the Beams it receives from the Sun before his rising, and after his setting; you have not that Light of Grace (as I may call it) which growing greater by degrees, doth more agreably prepare you for the arrival of the Sun, and which growing weaker, and diminishing by degrees, doth insensibly prepare you for the Sun's departure: But you are in a profound darkness, where a Curtain (as it were) is drawn all on a sudden, your Eyes are immediately dazled with the whole light of the Sun, in all its glory and brightness; so likewise, you are on a sudden surpriz'd with utter Darkness; the Night and the Day have no medium between them, but you fall in a moment from one extreme into the other. The Rainbow likewise is not known to them in the Moon; for if the Dawn is an effect of the grossness of the Air and Vapours, the Rainbow is form'd in the Clouds, from whence the Rain falls; so that the most beautiful things in the World, are produc'd by those things which have no beauty at all. Since then there are no Vapours thick enough, nor no Clouds of Rain about the Moon, farewell Dawn, adieu Rainbow: What must Lovers do for Similies in that Countrey, when such an inexhaustible Magazine of Comparisons is taken from them?

explanations: The French "Le changement de spectacle" (change of scene/sight) uses a specific visual/theatrical metaphor. The translation simplifies this to "This change" (occurring in the phrase "This change in our Imaginations"), omitting "de spectacle" and thus losing the specific metaphorical layer, making the description more general.

The French "fort grossier" (very coarse/thick) includes an intensifier "fort" (very). The translation uses "gross" (in the phrase "and being gross"), omitting this intensifier, which reduces the specific intensity of the description and simplifies the nuance.

The French phrase "il pourroit bien n'être pas si propre" (it could well not be as suitable) conveys a hypothetical possibility regarding the air. The translation renders the corresponding part as "not so proper", but this is preceded in the full sentence by "and therefore", which simplifies the original's tentative nuance by framing the air's property as a direct consequence. Additionally, the French "à renvoyer en en bas les rayons" (to send back down the rays) is simplified to "to send down the Beams."

The French phrase "comme de nuance en nuance" (as if from shade to shade, or nuance to nuance) offers a poetic and rich imagistic description of gradual fading. The translation "diminishing by degrees" is more prosaic and less evocative, simplifying the original's stylistic richness and sensory detail.

The French vividly describes both being in bright light ("vous êtes dans une lumière vive & éclatante") and then the sudden fall into darkness ("vous voilà tombés dans des tenebres profondes"). The English translation omits the explicit description of being in bright light and simplifies the dramatic physical image "vous voilà tombés dans" (there you are fallen into) to the more abstract "you are on a sudden surpriz'd with," reducing descriptive detail and the original's impactful imagery.

The French describes the transitional phase as "un milieu qui tienne de l'un & de l'autre" (a medium that partakes of/borrows from both). The English translation simplifies this by rendering the idea of the medium as "a medium between them" (within the larger "no medium between them"), thereby omitting the descriptive clause "qui tienne de l'un & de l'autre." This reduces the richness by losing the specific nuance about the medium's nature of partaking of both states.

The French "nous devons ... à celles qui le sont le moins" (we owe... to those which are [beautiful] the least) is a nuanced statement. The translation simplifies this by changing the agency and phrasing from "nous devons ... à" (we owe ... to) to "are produc'd by." More significantly, the subtle "qui le sont le moins" (which are so the least / are least beautiful) becomes the more absolute and explicit "which have no beauty at all," simplifying the original's subtlety for directness.

The French presents two concise, evocative phrases: a question about what the "Belles" (Beauties/beautiful women) of the Moon will be like without these phenomena ("& à quoy ressembleront les Belles de ce Pays-là?") and an exclamation about the lost poetic resource ("Quelle source de comparaisons perduë!"). The English translation replaces these with a single, more elaborate question that makes the implied cultural connections to "Lovers" and "Similies" explicit. This simplifies the interpretative work for the reader by narrowing the open-endedness of the first French question and transforming the poignant exclamation into a more direct statement of consequence, reducing the original's suggestive richness.

chunks.sourceHtml: P048: Je n'aurois pas grand regret à ces comparaisons là, dit la Marquise, & je trouve qu'on est assez bien recompense dans la Lune, de n'avoir ny Aurore ny Arc-en- ciel, car on ne doit avoir par la même raison ny Foudres ny Tonnerres, puisque ce sont aussi des choses qui se forment dans les nüages. On a de beaux jours toûjours serains pendant lesquels on ne perd point le Soleil de venë. On n'a point de nuits où toutes les Etoiles ne se montrent; on ne connoît ny les orages, ny les tempêtes, ny tout ce qui paroît être un effet de la colere du Ciel, trouvez-vous qu'on soit tant à plaindre? Vous me faites voir la Lune comme un séjour enchanté, répondis-je; cependant je ne say s'il est si délicieux d'avoir toûjours sur la tête, un Soleil ardent dont aucun nüage ne modère la chaleur. Peut-être aussi est-ce à cause de cela que la Nature a creusé dans la Lune des especes de Puits, qui sont assez grands pour être apperçus par nos Lunettes; car ce ne sont point des Vallées qui soient entre des Montagnes, ce sont des creux que l'on voit au milieu de certains lieux plats. Que sait-on si les Habitans de la Lune, incommodez par l'ardeur perpetuelle du Soleil, ne se refugient point dans ces grands Puits? Ils n'habitent peut-être point ailleurs, c'est là qu'ils bâtissent leurs Villes. Nous voyons icy que la Rome soûterraine êtoit presque aussi grande que la Rome qui est sur Terre. Il ne faudroit qu'ôter celle-cy, le reste seroit une Ville à la manière de la Lune. Tout un Peuple est dans un Puits, & d'un Puits à l'autre il y a des chemins soûterrains pour la communication des Peuples. Vous vous moquez de cette vision, j'y consens de tout mon cur; cependant, à vous parler tres serieusement, vous pourriez vous tromper plutôt que moy. Vous croyez que les Gens de la Lune doivent habiter sur la surface de leur Planete, parce que nous habitons sur la surface de la nôtre: c'est tout le contraire, puisque nous habitons sur la surface de notre Planete, ils pourraient bien n'habiter pas sur la surface de la leur. D'icy là il faut que toutes choses soient bien différentes.
chunks.manualHtml: P037: I doubt not, said the Countess, but there are those in the Moon as good at Simily as the greatest Beau in Covent-Garden; and had they neither Sun nor Stars, Pearls nor Rubies, Roses nor Lillies, yet could say as many fine things to a Visor-Mask, as the pertest Wit at the Puppet Show; and they are well enough recompenc'd for the loss of our Dawn and Rainbow; for by the same reason, they have neither Thunder nor Lightning, both which are formed in the Clouds; how glorious are their days, the Sun continually shining? How pleasant their Nights, not the least Star is hid from them? They never hear of Storms or Tempests, which certainly are an effect of the wrath of Heaven: Do you think then they stand in need of our pity? You are describing the Moon, I reply'd, like an enchanted Palace; but do you think it is so pleasant to have a scorching Sun always over our Heads, and not the least Cloud to moderate its Heat? Tho' I fancy 'tis for this reason that Nature hath made great Cavities in the Moon; we can discern 'em easily with our Tellescopes, for they are not Mountains, but so many Wells or Vaults in the middle of a Plain; and what do we know but the Inhabitants of the Moon, being continually broil'd by the excessive heat of the Sun, do retire into those great Wells; perhaps they live no where else, and 'tis there they build 'em Cities; for we still see in the Ruines of old Rome, that that part of the City which was under ground, was almost as large as that which was above ground. I fancy, during the late siege of Buda, they liv'd there as they do in the Moon, or 'tis but going to the Fountain Tavern Cellar, where the several Vaults are as so many high Streets, the Vats, Pipes, Hogsheads, so many different Edifices, and the Drawers and Coopers, like so many Troglodites. I perceive you laugh at me, yet if I may be so free with a fair Lady, you deserve it much better than I; for you believe the People in the Moon must live upon the surface of their Planet, because we do so upon ours; but quite contrary, since we dwell upon the Superficies of our Planet, they should not dwell upon the superficies of their Planet; if things differ so much in this World, what must they do in another?
